summary: Dr. Don Shirley is a world-class African-American pianist who's about to embark on a concert tour in the Deep South in 1962. In need of a driver and protection, Shirley recruits Tony Lip, a tough-talking bouncer from an Italian-American neighborhood in the Bronx. Despite their differences, the two men soon develop an unexpected bond while confronting racism and danger in an era of segregation.

I love this movie.  Touching, true and heart rending.  The 2 main characters forged an unlikely friendship which, in reality, lasted  for the rest of their lives and is captured perfectly by some great acting. This is an unforgettable movie.

This is a fantastic movie. From the first moment, the two main leads are on screen, I was engrossed in the movie. They both play off each other incredibly well. I would recommend this movie to everyone and anyone. I don't know how I missed it when it came out but I regret not being able to see this on the big screen. I wish all other media would sit down, watch this movie, and take notes. This is how you write a good-quality movie on breaking down racial and social barriers in a way that is not condescending. It tells a story instead of preaching a message. However, it has a great message to say.

"Зеленая книга" объединяет прищемленного итало-американского шофера с пианистом ямайского происхождения из высшего общества в фильме, которые отправляются на юг в период расовой сегрегации в Америке.. Открытая расовая нетерпимость, изображенная в фильме, отражает недавнее время, когда хорошо образованный, в высшей степени талантливый и богатый цветной человек, путешествующий по Югу, подвергался опасности. Если кажется, что "Зеленая книга" ведет себя так, будто такой расизм исчез, предлагает послание о важности сопереживания тем, кто находится за пределами вашей культурной сферы, независимо от их расы, сексуальной ориентации или религии.

Али Махершала играет доктора Дона Ширли, вундеркинда с множеством докторских степеней; он говорит на нескольких языках и играет  Шопена и Чайковского лучше, чем кто-либо другой; Для запланированного  концертного тура, в котором его трио, басист (Майк Хаттон) и виолончелист (Димитар Маринов), отправляется на Глубокий Юг, он просит об услугах водителя, который также будет телохранителем.
Тони Валлелонга (Вигго Мортенсен), уроженец Бронкса и вышибала из клуба. Тони также имеет укоренившиеся предубеждение об афроамериканцах, о чем свидетельствует сцена, когда его любящая жена Долорес (Линда Карделлини) предлагает двум чернокожим водопроводчикам стакан лимонада. Тони реагирует тем, что выбрасывает пустые стаканы в мусорное ведро, в ответ на это Долорес не высказывает недовольства, несмотря на спасение посуды для питья. Тем не менее, Тони соглашается на работу, учитывая высокую зарплату и обещание Ширли, что они вернутся к Рождеству.

Сценарий Ника Валлелонги, Брайана Карри и Фаррелли делает каждую реплику Тони убедительной, не важно, демонстрирует он свою узкую точку зрения, успешно обманывает кого-то или хвастается своей победой в конкурсе по поеданию хот-догов. Люди по соседству называют его болтун", если использовать его слова, — способный убедить других делать то, чего они не хотят. Есть сцена, где Тони, пораженный тем, что Ширли никогда не пробовала KFC убеждает его попробовать — "Но ваши люди любят жареную курицу" — говорит он, убеждая эрудированного работодателя есть пальцами. Ширли, тем временем, пытается привить этичность, далекому от этикета водителю, что продемонстрировано в сцене, где Ширли противостоит Тони из-за кражи камня у придорожного торговца.

Упомянутая книга, основана на "Зеленой книге негра-автомобилиста" Виктора Гюго Грина, и на «Путеводителе по путешествиям», двух путеводителях, предназначенных для того, чтобы помочь чернокожим водителям найти гостеприимные рестораны, жилье у дороги и автомобильные услуги. Беспрепятственное передвижение по дорогам было романтической концепцией Америки, но это также было заблуждением, поскольку афроамериканцы, путешествующие на машине могли оказаться остановленными полицией или бандой расистов без причин, кроме цвета кожи. Простое право передвигаться без преследований, казалось бы, улучшенное за последние пятьдесят лет, остается под вопросом, учитывая количество полицейских перестрелок с участием афроамериканцев.

Real stories reflecting human connections in a time of discord. We can learn from these stories to continue to be better. Not perfect but the lessons and tough discussions around race, where we were and are as a community are essential for growth.

This film is an absolute Masterpiece that deserves all the Praises it's been getting,the chemistry between these two characters is truly outstanding and after I was done watching I felt every emotion there is, this film is undoubtedly one of the greatest film ever made and stands as a reminder of what a movie should be.

Greenbook is a very interesting and enjoyable film to watch about the real life story of a working class white Italian becoming friends with a highly musically talented Black man in 1960's America. It explores the racism and homophobia of the times in the North and Southern United States. 
However, I must say that it definitely didn't deserve to win best picture at the Oscars. This was a 3/4 star film and at best should've only been nominated. Movies similar such as Shawshank Redemption, Green Mile and Driving Miss Daisy were 4/4 star films and thus were better than Greenbook and deserved Best Picture. I think this film won for two reasons, 1. Their weren't that many other good films that came out the same year. And 2. The Oscars at times tend to pick films that are about something serious like racism, etc.
really touching, I love this movie so much

This is quite a well made period drama - it certainly looks like it had a decent budget. There's a good cast and it feels suitably atmospheric. Its a somewhat thoughtful film I suppose, given the story, a fairly well known story I suppose (a novel by Charles Dickens), though I wasn't familiar with it personally, other than by name. I'm not sure there's much I can say about it - I'm not too keen on David Walliams - I'm not exactly a fan of him normally and it felt a little 'off' to have him appear in such a period film but perhaps I'm a little unfair? judge for yourself and also it goes without saying that Helena Bonham Carter is very much suited to her role - I imagine she enjoyed playing Miss Haversham very much and she certainly looks the part, as the gothic, somewhat ghostly lady living in a dark and run down mansion/house of sorts. Yes, overall I would recommend this as a decent film of its type.

Quite simply, a beautiful, beautiful film. If there's movie perfection elsewhere, then it's honoured to be in the same elite club as Green Book. This is one that has me laughing, crying, sombre, touched... the whole gamut of feelings, but also entranced from start to finish. The wonderful, complex, sparring, evolving and mutually enlightening relationship between Don and  Tony is exquisitely portrayed which makes it one of those rare cinematic experiences that truly encompasses more than its two hours ten minutes might promise. The balance in Green Book impresses me too, with themes of family, race, friendship, the scourge of intolerance and the liberation of acceptance combined in such a natural, spontaneous way that I'd recommend this as more or less essential viewing for film makers wanting to treat with these theses - this one gets it right, guys. And - the music is fabulous!

My main reason for watching 'Green Book' was due to me wanting to see as many 2018 films as possible, and that it had won the Best Picture Oscar (so naturally wanted to see too that it was that good). Like Viggo Mortensen as an actor, the film's concept was appealing and it looked appetising. Word of mouth, including from very trusted friends online and in real life, was very positive so there were plenty of other reasons too.

'Green Book' turned out to be when watching a very good film and nearly a great one with many fantastic things. Wouldn't go as far to say that it is my favourite film of 2018, and as far as the other Best Picture nominees go there was a preference for 'Roma' and 'The Favourite', but if to put it in a group of either best, solid middle and worst films of the year 'Green Book' would be closest to being in the best category of those three groups. It is a very, very well done film and its good intentions are evident throughout and noble.

It could have done with more grit in places, really do appreciate that it was trying not to be heavy-handed or trying to offend with a quite heavy theme but they could have done more with it and given a little more depth to what there was. Not saying it wasn't there, quite the contrary, just wish there was more.

Credit is due for the laudable and successful efforts in making the story accessible and it is one that easy to like and get into, but actually it could have afforded to do a little more risk-taking and have a little more complexity.

Viggo Mortensen though brings a lot of charm and entertainment value to his role, and Mahershala Ali is a dignified and very moving contrast. Their chemistry is wholly natural and beautifully irresistible (never feeling contrived or rushed) which provides a lot of 'Green Book's' heart, while their characters are more than just characters and instead feel very human. This is very different territory for director Peter Farrelly and it is surprisingly restrained direction from him and it suits the material very well. It's a lovely looking film too and affectionately photographed, while the music is beautifully chosen and fitted some nice nostalgic song choices here.

The script is thoughtful, charming and also moving, and regardless of anybody feeling that it is a little too accessible and could have done with more grit the story kept me riveted and left me moved, inspired and like my heart had been warmed. The YMCA scene is a powerful one and a character development turning point handled beautifully.

Summing up, one of those very good and nearly great films. 8/10

Beautiful film that contains a very explicit and very deep moral. In the end, the film is a story of mutual personal growth of the two protagonists who gradually become more and more friends in the film and help each other '' grow ''. Truly a wonderful film that tells a wonderful story

Green Book is a feel-good drama movie inspired from a true story. It is a master class in filmmaking in which every role acts well and the picture is awesome. I saw a lot of people recommending this movie on the internet. This movie not only won three Oscar awards for Best Picture, Best Film Editing, and Best Original Screenplay, but also won Best Actor and Best Supporting Actor. From all I've heard, I had  very high expectations for this movie and it turns out it didn't let me down and even better than I thought it would.

A story is about a relationship between black touring pianist Don Shirley and his white Italian personal driver Tony Lip by the main subjects is to reflect funny given its rather serious social setting of racial discrimination in 1960s America but funny is still given along the movie. Tony Vallelonga used to be a bouncer at  a 1960s nightclub in New York but ended up as a temporary personal driver to African-American pianist Don Shirley. They need to carry The Green Book, a guide to hotels and restaurants hospitable to black people during the drive down south. The movie includes sexual identity subject once then moves on without any other discussion. The two characters are contrasted in both personality and social status but they get to learn from each other during this 8 weeks drive. Don is a virtuoso who has a snobbish manner. He always responds to every racial slight and stands for himself which is really inspiring and impressive. Conversely, Tony is a chill person. He represents an ignorant person who wouldn't take any action in racism. Their road trip makes them have self-discovery as well as exploring other different societies. 

Overall, I think The Green Book is a really great movie that has an impact on the subject about racism along the route of road-tripping with the guide book. It is really inspiring in terms of maintaining self dignity and reminds me to always respect others and also my own self.

This film is a wonderful example of how biography, comedy, and drama can all work together. I had never heard of or read about this film before seeing it, which gave me an unexpected thought about it. At first, I believe that this film will be similar to other biographical films that I have seen in the past, boring and unpersuasive. However, after watching it for ten minutes, I am blown away by what I perceive. This film has taught me something new that I didn't know before, and the actors are completely immersed in their characters.

Dr. Don Shirley, an African American intelligent pianist, and Tony Lip, a tough bouncer hired to be Dr. Don's personal driver since the nightclub where he previously worked was closed for renovations, were initially unimpressed in one other. They have no idea what each other has gone through or what they need to be face with. Taking us back to that time, even if he was a great pianist, the black guy constantly struggled to acquire respect from others. Despite the fact that many people want to listen to the music he performs, they nevertheless act as though black people are not on the same level as them. Even if they didn't say it out loud, their actions did.

The film depicts the development of characters while also showing the progress of their relationship. It's as though they're demonstrating that even people with opposing personalities may one day open their hearts to one another. This film is of the biography genre and is based on a true story so that the viewer may understand how black people were treated in the past. The Negro Motorist Green Book, a guideline for black people's safety on the road, is an excellent illustration of how people thought in the past. The messages that this film conveys are very strong, especially in terms of friendship and the problem of racism, as can be seen.

Despite the fact that the film deals with the extremely stressful and heavy topic of "racism," it nonetheless has some comedy. To conclude, this is one of the greatest biographical films that I have seen so far, and I would suggest it to anybody who is interested in those topics or just want to see a film that has a fantastic mix of everything. Out of ten, I definitely give this film score of 9.5!

Great movie that told a beautiful story about personal growth and evolving beyond race and color for a small town Italian from New York. Characters developed subtly and smoothly to show a genuine human connection. Excellent movie, definitely worth the watch!
A great movie which shows racism in both ways in a comical way. Would recommend to everybody, a must see which breaks through a lot of stereotypes.
Loved it. Lot funnier and different than I expected.

Peliculón en todos los aspectos, la química de los personajes es increíble, la trama y como se desenvuelve es muy orgánica, el mensaje tan fuerte que tiene al estar basada en una historia de la vida real es un plus, Mahershala Ali hace una de sus mejores actuaciones.
Awesome movie. Really great characters. Definitely a bit weird how feel good it is when you think about the subject matter but hey.

Green Book is a masterclass in filmmaking. Every role, no matter how big or small is well-acted and the story flows seamlessly. A story about a relationship between black touring piano virtuoso Don Shirley and his white Italian bodyguard driver Tony Lip sounds relatively mundane on paper, but the movie is remarkably funny given its rather serious social setting of racial discrimination in 1960s America. The movie sends a clear message about the inhumanity of racial discrimination with its underpinnings of control and power and how human connection can transcend racial barriers, but it's the character Don Shirley's response to every racial slight that leaves an inspiring and lasting impression. The character chooses dignity above all else and suffers not only humiliation but also the pain of self-restraint. The movie ends on an uplifting note, but it is the quiet anguish of a dignified response in the face of oppression that will be remembered.

A moving story told with a touch of humour. It also let you see two sides of an important social issue. I find this movie a real joy to watch. Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali both pulled of an amazing job.

I loved this because it's a feel-good, easy-to-watch movie. I don't believe it should win best picture Oscar because it's cringingly predictable and formulaic.  But it's entertaining and heart-warming and based on a true story.  Perhaps it's an educational eye-opener for youngsters who aren't already aware of the segregation and racism prevalent in the southern US States at that time.
This movie don't want to be good, it only wants be kindly with me, the viewer, which is possible through the performance of Mahershala Ali. 7/10

I love it. There are a lot of morals in this story. This movie is a mixture of a lot of feelings. This made me smile and cry at the same time.

Green Book tackles a difficult, complex issue and plays with the audience's heartstrings. Unfortunately it falls back on stereotypes to illustrate points instead of focusing on the relationship between Tony and the Dr. A powerful film, but one that needs more fine tuning to be truly successful.
terrible film. maybe the worst film to ever win the academy for best picture...
Good movie, certainly a grower. Typical 60's vibe, about how life was like as a famous black guy traveling in the southern states.  Good acting throughout.

You'd think we'd learn, wouldn't you? Men are not the heroes of stories about misogyny, nor are white people the heroes of stories about racism in 1960's Amercia. And yet, just when we thought Driving Miss Daisy was out of the system, here's Green Book winning an inexplicable Best Picture Oscar in 2019. I'd put this off for a long time, but this time the Random Film Generator gave me no choice, and I really tried to keep an open mind. But this is a clod-hoppingly cloying, naive, sometimes downright insulting racism drama that's elevated by two quite brilliant performances from Mahershala Ali (no coincidence that his Oscar was for Supporting Role rather than Leading ...) and Viggo Mortensen. They are in a different film altogether, one with grace notes, subtleties and intelligence that they must have mined from somewhere other than screenplay or direction. Recognition for the likes of Moonlight and Parasite in recent years don't make up for the elevation of this very ordinary film to heights and publicity it doesn't deserve (central performances aside), but they suggest that there may be some forward steps being taken. Sometimes. Meanwhile, if you must watch this, do so for the acting.

I thought it was an enjoyable movie overall as it brings to life the story of Don Shirley and Tony Lip in 1962 as they traveled through the South for musical performances and the friendship they formed along the way. It also brings to light the terrible time of racial segregation in the south for blacks and the hatred they faced from whites which Tony didn't see in the beginning, but soon changed and bonded with Dr. Shirley. It was a great story about the time period and made me want to learn more about it and their lives

Green book succeeds at hitting your heart strings while informing you of the awful ways in early American times. Viggo Mortenson does an amazing and convincing performance, usually stealing the screen along side Mahershala Ali making an all and all perfect film.

Green Book is undeniably heart warming. I think those who have cast this movie as irreverent, flip, or even dangerous concerning its very subject matter had very preconceived notions about the type of movie this SHOULD be as opposed to the movie that it is. It isn't hard hitting, it isn't entirely realistic, but I would in no way describe it as irreverent to the suffering that black Americans have endured. Green Book is at most times a breezy comedy about 2 men learning to become friends. It seldom is anymore than that and I really don't believe it is trying to be either outside of a few tonal set-piece moments. Did it deserve its Best Picture win? No, I don't think so at all. It was very enjoyable though.
Great movie. Good blend of funny and serious. Could have used a bit more emotion though, that's the only thing that keeps this from being a perfect film to me.
I liked that movie very much!
Great dialogue, would definitely recommend. 9/10

Very good.  Not great but I recommend watching as I love the cast and the performances.
Great acting and the plot was great. It showed racial problems back in the 60s as it is.
Brilliant...there's very little else to say about this movie....just, well...brilliant.
One of my favorite movies of last couple years. Very funny and deep at the same time.

"Green Book" despite not having much impact or beautiful explanations about the issues presented, the actors' efforts gave a "glorious charm", giving sympathy to the characters and making the film, until the end of the journey, very pleasant and comforting.
It's a perfect story of a good friendship. Very perfectly performed by actors.
The fact that this beat BlacKkKlansman at the academy awards is pathetic. Green Book is a watchable but problematic film. It's not bad per se, just not a worthy Best Picture winner.

Summary: Frank "Tony Lip" Vallelonga, a gruff bouncer looking to make extra cash, and Dr. Don Shirley, a talented pianist and no-nonsense professional, embark on a music tour to the south. The color of their skin isn't the only difference between these men. The odd pairing is actually based on a true friendship.

Takeaways: The film is named after The Negro Motorist Green Book, a real guidebook to keep Black folks safe during cross-county travels. Dr. Shirley can only hope music will overcome the persistent southern racism.
Awesome movie. Very interesting plot and the cast is amazing.

Well, there are lots of stories revolving around how black people are treated and how homosexual people are treated. What we see is a character who is at the side of the struggled in both. Not only that, this man is also a virtuoso who is a respected man and he hires another man who is most likely an uneducated heterosexual white man. Consequently, this is a duo of opposing sides. What is more interesting is how these two men educate each other and how they teach each other what they are really missing. There was a also a confrontation scene near the ending between two men that I actually saw how good acting can encapsulate the audience into the film world. Actors were spectacular. The movie has a lot of things to process and it handles all of them brilliantly. On top of all, it is fun and inspiring.

This is what i see as the best film created in modern time.
A complete eyeopener and a reflection of the now. Amazing Acting and fantastic storytelling with a beautiful ending.
Fun parts were very good 😊

Just a boring and mediocre movie. The source material, like the acting, is good, but this does not save the lack of humor, insipid storytelling and faded directing

Best picture winner at the 2019 Academy Awards, many said this was an underwhelming winner and that other films (e.g. The Favourite) deserved it more. To be fair, there wasn't much competition for best picture - with films like Black Panther and Bohemian Rhapsody up for the nod it must have been a slow year.

This film certainly has its qualities but doesn't really excel anywhere. The message of racism in the film and its exploration was very on the nose and quite simplistic (I thought BlacKkKlansman was better in this regard). While these issues of course are very important to explore, it feels as though they were played up as Oscar bait. Overall the film is perfectly fine and has good performances from the two leads. At the very least it's nowhere near as bad as that infamous best picture winner Crash (2004).
I enjoyed this movie

Well acted and well made.  Unique friendship of male bonding by two more different people.  A black classical musical genius (also holding Ph.D's in literature I believe and other things) and a wheeling dealing Italian American Coco Cabana night club bouncer from the Bronx.  The white man shows the black man his heritage while the black man shows the white man his own faults and qualities.

This was such a poignant movie.  It shows that we are individuals, not stereotypical groups and when we come to know each other in that way, we can find common ground and grow to appreciate each other.  I love that there's not political message, there doesn't have to be.

While you can apply cliches like "feel good movie" and "it's not about the destination but about the journey", the things that really elevate Green Book are lots of little details and how it serves up elements of drama wrapped up on in postive vibes that make it really fun to watch.

A story of a Black musical genius braving a tour through the very-racist South. Yet the main character is a White man.
Nice going, Dreamworks!

I was annoyed by the amount of racism in this. Should have been called Racist Road 
Trip.

Green Book is a film that features inspiring performances by Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali and a script that fully engages the viewer. Although the narrative is well treated in making us care for the characters, the film fails to treat in the right way that it should be the target of the film, racism. Rather than proposing uncomfortable situations where the protagonist reflects on his racist actions, the script sometimes seems to contribute to many of them, as in the scene where the driver is surprised that his contractor has never eaten fried chicken and offers it to him, which when eat, like and so the scene ends. The public is led to have the same understanding as that of Tony Lip, about all black people liking fried chicken, an extremely racist position, but treated with a surreal normality in the film.
While the performances are admirable, the film is decidedly not.

8.75/10. A warm story about people seeing past differences to see basic humanity in one another. Ali and Mortensen bring the script and characters to life with some of their best work to date. It's a familiar story, but top-tier acting, solid direction (though a touch breezy/sappy in points), and some great music make it a story worth revisiting.

Green Book is a classic case of a movie with its heart in the right place that winds up tripping all over itself and falling flat on its face.  In a nutshell, the film is about Tony Lip (Vito Mortensen), a tough guy from the Bronx, who is hired to accompany black pianist Donald Shirley (Mahershala Ali) on a concert tour of the racially divided southern United States in 1962.  While Ali is fantastic from start to finish, Mortensen, despite the accolades heaped upon him, at times overplays his part to the point where it's laughable.  While the movie has its share of impactful moments, it all seems to fall apart over the final act with a shameful ending that seems to be torn from the script of Planes, Trains and Automobiles.  What worked so beautifully for Steve Martin and John Candy fails miserably in Green Book, an attempt to make the audience feel good about a problem that has plagued America for centuries.
Como intocable pero peor

Very strong story about the life of black Americans in the 60s. We have a beautiful performance by Viggo Mortensen as Tony "lip" Vallelonga, a stereotyped, brutish and prejudiced Italian, however, who accepts the job of driver of Mr. Shirley (Mahershala There) to take you through several states in the south of the United States, known for being a typically prejudiced region. We were able to empathize with Tony, who despite all his faults, still loves and does everything for his family, and for Shirley, an unparalleled skill that has become his gift and his curse. He is a pianist genius, and while people admire him for his art, they despise him for being black. Because of this dichotomy, he feels lost, belonging nowhere, on the one hand, being an educated person with values ​​totally different from his peers, on the other, a black man, whom many white people despise. We can easily understand his feelings because we are often lost too, not knowing what to do. It is a film that deserves to be seen and appreciated, only losing in some liberties that the film uses in relation to the life of both to make the film more salable.

The old adage "Walk a mile in someone else's shoes" takes a whole new meaning with this delightful film. It also proves another proverb true, "To really know someone, travel with them." 
I almost didn't recognize my beloved Viggo, previously cemented as Aragorn in a classic trilogy. But his depiction of Tony Vallelonga in this movie is really memorable, he slides into the role with the same ease as he digs into a bowl of homemade pasta and meatballs. A worldly wisdom, a straightforward honesty, and a strong moral code of a man who grew up in rough streets. Swift with the blunt fists and the sharp words alike. 
Mahershala Ali as Shirley was also really well played, a man truly lost between worlds, belonging to none, with a blistering genius that only increases his isolation. One truly feels sorry for his self deprecating analysis as a puppet on strings, an erudite carnival showman, a bizarre exhibit surrounded by racism. 
The lovely message of this movie is the ability of these two men to learn from each other, to embrace each other's world views, and in the end to valiantly rise in friendship and mutual respect. We could all learn from their journey, especially to never underestimate the knowledge and wisdom we can share to become better people.
As with any period piece I adored the authentic reproduction of a bygone ‘simpler' age steeped in dark racism and hate. The nostalgia of the past is a dangerous thing when it whitewashes what really happened in sundown towns and plantations, even after the civil war. The Green Book is as insidious a piece of literature as Mein Kampf, born from the same cauldron of hate.
Great story with two amazing actors. A movie that is sure to leave a smile on your face.

In 1962 New York City, bouncer Tony Lip (Viggo Mortensen) searches for new employment after the nightclub he works at, Copacabana, is closed for renovations. He is invited to an interview with Dr. Don Shirley (Mahershala Ali), a black pianist in need of a driver for his eight-week concert tour through the Midwest and Deep South. Don hires Tony on the strength of his references. They embark with plans to return to New York City on Christmas Eve. Don's record label gives Tony a copy of the Green Book, a guide for African-American travelers to find motels, restaurants, and filling stations that would serve them. They begin the tour in the Midwest before eventually heading farther south. Tony and Don initially clash as Tony feels uncomfortable being asked to act with more refinement, while Don is disgusted by Tony's habits. As the tour progresses, Tony is impressed with Don's talent on the piano, and is increasingly appalled by the discriminatory treatment which Don receives from his hosts and the general public when he is not on stage. A group of white men beat Don and threaten his life in a bar and Tony rescues him. He instructs Don not to go out without him for the rest of the tour. Throughout the journey, Don helps Tony write letters to his wife Dolores (Linda Cardellini), which deeply move her. Tony encourages Don to get in touch with his own estranged brother, but Don is hesitant, observing that he has become isolated by his professional life and achievements...

Rotten Tomatoes critical consensus reads: "Green Book takes audiences on a surprisingly smooth ride through potentially bumpy subject matter, fueled by Peter Farrelly's deft touch and a pair of well-matched leads." Writing for The San Francisco Chronicle, Mick LaSalle praised Ali and Mortensen and said: "...there's something so deeply right about this movie, so true to the time depicted and so welcome in this moment; so light in its touch, so properly respectful of its characters, and so big in its spirit, that the movie acquires a glow. It achieves that glow slowly, but by the middle and certainly by the end, it's there, the sense of something magical happening, on screen and within the audience." Steve Pond of TheWrap wrote, "The movie gets darker as the journey goes further South, and as the myriad indignities and humiliations mount. But our investment in the characters rarely flags, thanks to Mortensen and Ali and a director who is interested in cleanly and efficiently delivering a story worth hearing."

"Green Book" is inspired by the true story of a tour of the Deep South by African American classical and jazz pianist Don Shirley and Italian American bouncer Frank "Tony Lip" Vallelonga who served as Shirley's driver and bodyguard. The film received numerous accolades and nominations, and at the 91st Academy Awards, it won Oscars for Best Picture, Best Original Screenplay, and Best Supporting Actor for Ali. Personally I think that "Green Book" is predictable and "adjusted" with a story we have seen before with an interracial friendship that develop a mutual exchange of perspectives and common grounds. I think as well that this topic is not served all too well in a "comic" package due to the direction by Peter Farrelly. I felt the same with Spike Lee´s "BlacKkKlansman". But, that´s my personal point of view as I think the topic is difficult and it is as current as ever and I want it to be taken more seriously. We do get some great moments between Ali and Mortensen. But, I was ultimately not blown away as many others were. But, cred for the nice 60s settings. And I do like Linda Cardellini.

Esse filme diz tanta coisa que é difícil decidir por onde começar.

As duas personalidades apresentadas são bastante complexas, e suas evoluções ocorrem de uma maneira muito orgânica. Em outras palavras, podemos compreender muito bem o que está acontecendo com os mesmos.

Já no inicio, o filme deixa bem claro que Tony é racista - e pela atitude dele, não é pouco. Também fica claro que boa parte da sua família te essa conduta, e a convivência com eles apenas gera uma super bolha, qual ele está prestes a sair. Quanto ao Dr. Shirley, seu desenvolvimento acontece de maneira mais lenta e progressiva. As situações que o mesmo passa são absurdas, e em pouco tempo nos habituamos no ambiente predominantemente racista que a obra se passa. Com o tempo, as posições de Shirley ficam mais claras, e o embate entre os dois se torna bem interessante. É indiscutível que começamos com maus olhos no que se diz respeito ao Tony, mas alguns pontos que o mesmo levantou foram interessantíssimos. Toda a tragediaria que eles passaram fez com que Tony finalmente pudesse enxergar as coisas de uma maneira diferente, saindo da bolha que ele sempre esteve. Shirley também tem uma evolução significativa, com reflexões relacionadas ao próprio povo dele. Já no final da obra, temos uma cena de desabafo onde o ator "Mahershala Ali" que foi tão intensa a ponto de percebermos que aquilo transcende uma linha de dialogo. Aquelas palavras são algo que ele passa ou já passou, e isso deu uma intensidade absurda a cena, que por si só, tecnicamente, foi muito bem construída. Lembro de ficar todo arrepiado, e outra cena que me provocou o mesmo foi a primeira vez que o vi tocar.

Em decorrência das situações humilhantes que o Shirley passou, o diretor teve a brilhante ideia de refletir aquele peso no modo como Dr. tocava seu piano. A musica é a mesma, mas o tom, a raiva e todos os sentimentos que vem junto eram completamente diferentes. Outro contrate interessante foi na cena onde ele toca um gênero predominante na cultura negra, mas que o mesmo ignorara por conta da sua distancia com os mesmos. O momento que ele sobe no palco do bar e toca o que sabe é uma das minhas cenas favoritas desse filme. E logo após, vê-lo tocar com a banda presente no momento foi divertidíssimo.

O final foi demasiadamente satisfatório, e ele ainda me faz acreditar em determinadas pessoas.

Se tratando de aspectos técnicos, a fotografia é bem elegante, rendendo vários frames dignos. A atuação de Mahershala Ali eu já mencionei acima. A mixagem de som tá excelente, devo mencionar. E quanto aos momentos cômicos, eles me pegaram. Funcionam quase sempre, me rendendo ótimas gargalhadas.

In Green Book, actor Tony Lip (Viggo Mortensen) is hired as a chauffeur for musician Don Shirley (Mahershala Ali) after the Copacabana club shuts its doors. People, especially the ones at the Oscars, overcompensate the themes of racism and bigotry into this movie, when really it's anything but. Instead, it's your typical run-of-the-mill story about two polar opposites that at first bite each other and they turn up as friends in the end. While Peter Farrelly, Brian Currie and Nick Vallelonga sneak in the two motifs in the movie, Green Book tells its formulaic story like a race-swapped Driving Miss Daisy. However, when the 1960's racist politics pop up, it can be uncomfortably forced, like the "I'm not like most black people" moment where Shirley eats KFC for the first time. I guess this act is a symbol of friendship, but I just groan when the movie tries too hard to be anti-racist. Then again, I'm watching a movie titled after the African American segregation tour books at the time, so I guess I shouldn't complain too much. Then, there's this Planes, Trains and Automobiles moment in the end where Shirley arrives at Tony's place for his Christmas Eve party because Shirley's all alone in Carnegie Hall. With him being a famous person of his time, I can't help but strongly doubt that nobody in New York City would make a solitary attempt to throw a party for him, especially with all his trials and tribulations in the South. Despite its efforts, Green Book had unoriginal storylines, forced racial pandering to easy-to-please audiences, and a sappy Hollywood execution.

Ignore the critics - they theorise so much that they lost contact with earth and regular people. I do not think this movie was made to be an anthem or to tell us everything about racial issues in the US. It is not a philosophical document - it is a story based on facts about two man who become friends for the rest of their lives, despite strong cultural and social barriers. The chemistry that developed between the main two characters is the essence of this movie. This is the message that we need nowadays. Just two individuals becoming more sensitive and understanding to problems of others and who can count on each other when facing troubles or dangers. 
We do not need big institutions or big heads to fix the world. We only need to be like these two guys shown in this movie. Brotherhood among millions is almost impossible, but brotherhood between two souls is not only achievable but it is probably the strongest type of bond that can unite people of different races. There is a place in history for people like Luther King but everyday life circles around stories like this one. Law or institutional changes can only achieve so much but the real change happens at much lower level, in the heart of every man. It is not possible to truly love millions of people or to have meaningful relationship with them all but it is possible to find a soul mate in one person if we look outside of our social bubble. 
That message is very powerful and much underestimated or ignored by so called critics.

Hello, everyone! Some days ago I have seen the movie "Green Book" and even now I have the same emotions as I had during watching the film. As I know this film is enough new for us and was released in 2018 by Peter Farrelly. Also it's important to say that the genre of the film is biographical comedy-drama. 
This film is fantastic! On the one hand, it has really funny moments without any banality, but on the other hand, it has a really deep and thought-provoking plot. I've listened about this film so many times and had a fear that this film will be overrated, but I really erred – the film is brilliant! I want to mark the picture and setting of the film in particular. The music is splendid and well-chosen. It has an especial atmosphere that makes to feel that time. 
The director was inspired by the true story of two people: African American classical and jazz pianist Don Shirley and Italian American bouncer Frank Vallelonga that accompanied Don as driver and bodyguard in a tour to the Deep South. They had a lot of obstacles by way of disrespectful relations toward Don Shirley. And of course we see how characters change during their tour. The first person becomes simpler as a man but more respectful toward himself and the second person becomes more respectful toward others.
Thanks to outstanding cast "Green Book" became so realistic and so unparalleled. Mahershala Ali and Viggo Mortensen were really perfect and played in their characters as good as it was possible.

Green Book is a true-to-life, full of optimism story about a road trip of two man that lives radically different life. Their adventure started when a famous black pianist Don Shirley recruited heavy handed Italian security guard Tony Vallelonga. His job was to drive the musician safe to every concert on the road and cover his back in the meantime with a help of the titular green book. The plot has been set in 1962 so the historical context and difficult situation of black people back then in the USA is the premise of the movie. 
In my opinion Green Book is simply the most captivating lesson of tolerance that I have ever seen. The story is emotionally strong, full of poignant scenes of kindness and newly born friendship. But we can find there a lot of hilarious moments what makes a movie unquestionably enjoyable. 
I definitely recommend this film to everybody who wants to see some uplifting story with happy ending but requires something more ambitious than a popcorn movie.

A great story is buoyed by fabulous acting, some terrific situational drama, and just the right amount of hilarious malapropisms.

GB is comical and heartbreaking, occasionally in the same moment.  It perpetuates certain stereotypes while turning others on their head, all the while showing a humanity that inherently lies underneath them all.

Green Book was such a good movie about the true story between Tony V who was played by Viggo Mortensen and Dr. Donald Shirley who was a world renowned pianist who was played by Mahershala Ali. The two became such great friends that they were on the road for half the year traveling thru the Bible Belt with a Green Book in order to stay at hotels where colored folks may sleep for the night.  It was such a moving and emotional movie that it definitely deserved the 2028 Best Picture award at the Oscars.  Viggo definitely deserved an award just as much as Ali did.  The flick captured such great lines such as "The world is full of lonely people afraid of making the first move." It was a wonderful movie you can enjoy and learn that color of our skin cannot be a barrier in our society, that each of us are created equal.  Definitely check this one out.

A subtle movie that makes its points with action, showing us just a glimpse of what it was like in the southern states in the 1960s.   The Green Book was a real book that Negroes had to use to find out which hotels would accept them and which wouldn't.  The black person, in southern states, had few rights until the landmark civil rights bills of 1964-65.  This film shows us some of milder white reaction to black people.  Murders, lynchings are violence of all kinds was par for the course in these states.  The movie does a great job telling a true story -- one that involved a high-ranking official in the Kennedy administration to bring justice for Dr. Shirley.  
The soundtrack is the worst aspect of the film.  Only one song, "Slow Twistin'" by Chubby Checker is reminiscent of 1962.  If the filmmakers really wanted to set the mood for 1962 they would not have used songs from the 40s and 50s and pretended that was what Americans were listening to in 1962.
Great movie! Learned a lot about the 50's and the treatment of African American population  in the south. Excellent acting and writing.

The political ideologues have their tongues wagging about the white savior complex in this Best Picture Oscar winner, but that's a load of horse hockey. In general, we look at films and prestige TV in these terms: (a) Script: Does the narrative keep you engaged and wondering what will happen next? And, if applicable, is it meaningful? (b) Acting: Do the actors disappear into their roles, or merely mouth a script like Bogart? (c) Direction: Does it show some inspiration, or is it just a recording of performances? Green Book excels, we feel, in (a) and (b). The direction would not rival Vertigo, but it's adequate. What gives the picture life is the compelling narrative and characters. There's no white savior here. The two men change each other. Finally, there's nothing wrong with the occasional feel-good moment or happy ending. It's a movie of warmth. In that sense, yes, it's kind of a Christmas movie, too.

"Frequently, when someone tries to portray the overwhelming decade of the 1960s, they usually misuse the concept of discrimination towards African Americans, which is accurate to describe this social issue. Nevertheless, the way Peter Farrelly and staff go into detail about this social wretchedness embodying the psychological impact it has in the main character makes the film an outstanding one".
...
The year is 1962, and the film begins inside Copacabana restaurant where we get introduced the imposing personality of Tony Lip, an Italian descendant whose family came from a lower middle class coping with some financial difficulties. The way Viggo Mortensen performs the character is a proper model of then American racism; therefore he attempted to keep them out until the occasion arrived and Don Shirley appeared in his path, offering him a two-month lifetime opportunity. We all need to bear in mind the precise dates because, in real life, it was nearly a year they spent together. Despite his gifted pianist skills and his upper-class status, he was still a victim of the convulsed cultural impact. Both of them, during the film, learn from each other and fight against the unsettling behaviour of determined people. Although it may seem simple, their interaction is one of the primary reasons why it succeeds. Believe it or not, it arouses curiosity, reaches the climax when they finally let them know as they are, and sometimes it results as a plot twister due to the radical temperament change of each actor. It has been ages since I watched such a pleasant film; afterwards, I felt refreshed as though it renewed me.
...
The contextualisation was imperative to build up each one's personality; moreover, it was visually dazzling owing to the costumes, the space and the background advertisement of the decade. Comedy is present as well so that you won't be missing from genuine laughs. Everything appears to be perfectly balanced, even the role of secondary personages such as Tony's wife and the cheeky cards experience. I'm chuffed to bits!
...
On the whole, the film "Green Book" is an exceptional example of the conception of a masterpiece without spending loads of money in production and without creating plenty of trifling scenarios.

One of the weakest, and most baffling, picks ever for the Oscar for Best Picture. Green Book would be a pleasant, forgettable cable TV movie in 1996, but this one dimensional road movie is just not Oscar-worthy...with the exception of the terrific Mahershala Ali. Director Peter Farrelly is the wrong choice for this one, as he can't dig beneath the service of either the key relationship or the troubled setting. It's all too lightweight and episodic to score any points.  Farrelly just approaches it like another of his mismatched characters hit the road comedies.

Welp. I put it off long enough. After a couple decades of never missing a movie nominated for Best Picture at the Oscars (much less one than actually won) I let a full year go by before actually getting around to watching 'Green Book'. I thought maybe there would be a surprise waiting for me and that I'd judged it too harshly on appearances without merit, buuuuuuut....nope. While this might be a perfectly fine movie I just can't imagine how anyone - much less a bunch of people - watched this and said, "This is definitely the best movie I saw in all of 2018." I am simply baffled by it. 
It is completely devoid of original ideas whether they be thematic or cinematic and has all of the depth of something that would've been released on the topic of race 30 years ago. Surely, Hollywood can do better than this?

Heavy emphasis on the question mark above.

The 2018 Oscar winner for "Best Picture" was far from special, but was an enjoyable story with excellent acting. Dr. Shirley (Mahershala Ali) probably has the coolest bachelor pad ever — filled with items from faraway lands, on top of Carnegie Hall. The concept of the "Green Book," which was new to me, is fascinating. Viggo Mortensen as Tony "Lip" seemed a little too stereotypical of an Italian-American at first (think the first season of The Sopranos), but I thought he transitioned more smoothly as the film went on and really appreciated his performance by the end. That gigantic house that's supposed to be in Pittsburgh or Ohio somewhere (can't remember) is actually in New Orleans — went to law school with the girl who lives there. I liked that they didn't make the North/South divide a good/bad divide, as the first racist encounter was in Indiana — albeit, not directed to Dr. Shirley himself. One moment I found unrealistic was Dr. Shirley's arrest at the YMCA in Georgia. If this was factually true, so be it, but I found it unbelievable that a man of Dr. Shirley's intelligence would do something as foolish as engage in public, homosexual sex, in the Deep South at this time.

No idea what year this was released nor its backstory and if based on fact or fiction? But caught it twice over Xmas on Showtime and it really ripped my heart out having been raised both in the north and south in the 60's-70's as a kid right after segregation - and as a Caucasian that was bussed to all black schools, which definitely taught me a lot as a child... plus living in Texas for 15 more years (bussing was in Memphis) - I'm just sad and sometimes ashamed at our society on the whole (or humanity) that such even segregation existed only 40-50 years ago. And obviously remnants still remain today. But as for this film, as the Rotten Tomatoes write up says; it takes viewers on a ride thru a very bumpy topic (topics actually) - But is a must see for those that struggle with understanding the Mason Dixon line and "life in the south vs the north". The premise is an amazing canvass in which to tell this story (and ultimately the moral to the story) - and whilst uncomfortable at times to watch, the director or writer takes you right to the edge, then slowly backs away without too much violence or unnecessary conflicts, yet you will feel it in your soul. Extremely well written and acted and while I don't know the actors - the ending and their performances were just amazing. So after seeing it for a 2nd time, I decided to research it more and was thrilled to see its high audience rating on Rotten Tomatoes. So I'm not alone in thinking this is a great film 👍🏻  

Given the divided country and world we live in these days (2020) I think films like this (that are accurate/believable and in the end, all is well) offers hope when it seems we're all fighting daily and now internationally - and its just time for everyone to chill and realize there's more important things in life than careers or possessions or status. Our family and friends and stepping outside of our comfort zones and making the effort to mend bridges that were burnt decades ago - that definitely still need mending and this film is a great reminder of ways to help start healing some of those wounds - if even just one mans journey. It's hard to explain as I don't want to spoil the film - but think we all could use a large dose of forgiveness, empathy, compassion and most of all, forgiveness plus a better understanding of the larger world around us and that tolerance (or acceptance) of those different than us as this would go a very long way in laying down the first steps to a more peaceful and loving world. Lord know we definitely need it.

Let's be clear because it is something I didn't understand going into it. This is a movie about the white guy and how his attitude was changed by having the opportunity to be subservient to an obviously superiorly educated and superiorly capable black guy. I watched it because of Mahershala Ali, who I think is a really excellent actor. But this vehicle is flawed, so flawed. The Italian protagonist most likely kept in his memory afterwards that there was this one black guy who wasn't like the others. I doubt he changed his attitude toward our black fellow citizens in general.

And I have a great and lasting problem with the ridiculous title. The movie is not really about the experience of black people traveling through the south, it is about one white guy's introduction to this fact. Baaaaah. Watch it, sure. But I want very much a completely different story someday, with Mahershala Ali in the lead, that takes us through first hand what it was like to travel while black in the US deep South. Without some white guy to the rescue. 99.8% of the time, I am sure there wasn't one.

Green Book's subject matter is immensely serious and it juxtaposes this with a surprising amount of humour with two charming characters who have wonderful chemistry.

It was clearly aimed at securing oscars and certainly succeeded in that regard. The story is an uplifting and heartwarming one: two people from vary different backgrounds end up becoming unlikely friends, after some initial friction.

An absolute must-see in my book.

The first time i see Green Book, was before the Oscar awards ceremony. Actually i remember that the favorite to win "Best movie" was Rome from Alfonso Cuaròn.  "Caliente.MX"  a mexican bookmaker paid a lot of money for bet Green Book in best movie, also in the category of "Best Script" (Green Book was not the favorite either)... well, Green Book won both and i win money too. But... ¿Why? I decided to bet because after seeing all the movies that were nominated, in my personal opinon, Green Book was just amazing. 

The movie was directed by Peter Farreli who makes a magnifiscent work. The trama focus In the decade of the 60`s in USA when the racial segregation was going on, an ideological struggle beetween the north and the south. A black man who is a pianist, hire an italoamerican to make a musical tour in the south, the most racist part of America. 

Actually the movie is based on real events and was named Green Book because that`s the name of the guide from that time with all the places when the black people could go without problems. 

As Don Shirley wich is the piano man was performed by Mahershala Ali and the italian driver by Viggo Mortensen, the performances are more than excellent, the two fit perfectly and you can feel the chemistry.

Peter Farally's Green Book raised quite a few eyebrows (and set off a fair number of eye roles) when it won best picture at the Oscars. Audiences and critics have praised the film for its wit, humor, and committed lead performances, while detractors have accused it of being overly glib, and made disparaging comparisons to Driving Miss Daisy. In my humble opinion, the naysayers are mostly wrong. This isn't to say that Green Book is perfect, but I would consider it a very good movie.

Both Mortensen and Ali's performances are excellent, and together their chemistry is nothing short of incredible. As Tony Lip, Mortensen is rough, uncouth, and quick tempered, with a real mouth on him. And he's casually racist. Not the most likeable guy, at least until some of his employer's charm and smarts start to rub off on him. Mortensen makes the character work because he never sugar-coats who Tony is or tries too hard to make him likeable, but neither does he force the racism, turning him into a completely unlikable caricature.

For his part, Ali is keenly intelligent, sophisticated, semi-reserved, and just a bit eccentric as Don Shirley. He frequently brings a palpable frustration and annoyance, whether at ignorance and somewhat loose ethics of his new driver, or the less than ideal circumstances he finds himself in. But he always manages a level of self control befitting a man of his refinement. Well, nearly always. When the damn breaks and he lets loose it provides some of the movie's best emotional catharsis and deepest reflections on race and identity.

 And there are some very deep, frequently thought provoking, and often uncomfortable meditations on race and society, driven by some truly brilliant dialog. And as the movie goes on, they're increasingly inter-spaced with the lighthearted and genuinely heartwarming moments as the two men warm up to each other. There are some pretty funny moments, as seen in the trailer, and some truly wonderful music. Green Book is by no means a full on musical, but there's a lot of excellent piano playing, and a very fun blues performance towards the end.

Now I'd like to address some of the criticisms of this film. 
Despite what some critics have said, Green Book doesn't fall into the White Savior trope. Yes, Tony pulls Doctor Shirley out of some jams. He literally saves him from a close call at a bar. But that's what actually happened. And Shirley pulls him out of some tough spots too. Nor does it succumb to the "Magical Negro" trope. Much of the movie does revolve around how Shirley helps Tony learn and grow as a person. But it's not a one-sided relationship. Both men learn new things, see new viewpoints, and get a better idea of who they are as a result of their interactions, and if Tony has more growth, that's because he had a lot more growing to do in the first place.

It is true that the movie doesn't spend a whole lot of time addressing Shirley's homosexuality.  But it's not like they leave it out or tiptoe around, and between issues of race and class Green Book already has plenty of worthy issues on its plate. The filmmakers were never setting out to make another Moonlight. Now I would have liked to see more of the actual Green Book and its contents, which only appear briefly. I also found a few bits here and there a tad slow, and and the first half had more cringy and awkward moments than I would have liked, though perhaps that was unavoidable.

No, Green Book didn't deserve best picture, and I have no idea what the people at the Globes were smoking when they awarded it best musical or comedy. But it's a satisfying road movie, a deservedly feel good story about race, and one of the better films of 2018.

When I watched the 2019 Oscars and heard them call out "Green Book" for Best Picture, I thought to myself, "Damn, I have to watch the film that beat Bohemian Rhapsody", and was skeptical at first, but upon viewing was heartwarmed and very comprehensive of why Green Book took the 2018 Best Picture award rather than Bohemian Rhapsody. Watching Tony (Viggo Mortensen) and Don's (Mahershala Ali) journey together and seeing them overcome so many racial difficulties in the Deep South and remembering that all of this is true, that they really did have a real friendship, is deeply inspiring and significantly entertaining to watch. There is a reason it won Best Picture.

I watched Green Book without seeing any of the trailers and without knowing what it was about.  I was very pleasantly surprised to see such a self aware movie about a real friendship.  All the acting in this movie is very superb, as my favorite scenes in the movie came from this friendship between Tony Lip and Doctor Donald Shirley.  It was so fun and entertaining to watch these two characters grow together and look out for one another.  Some people complained about this movie not being totally accurate as the movie takes the segregation to a safe minimal.  The movie is PG-13 which I honestly thought was a smart choice.  This allows younger people to be able to watch the movie and still understand what the U.S. used to be like and how racism is wrong.  We don't always need rated R movies to tell us racism is bad, this movie can show everyone that it doesn't matter what skin color you have because we are all equal, and I thought that was really beautiful.  I do have to admit the beginning of the movie went a little slow for me.  I didn't like the opening sequence and didn't think it had much to do with the overall plot.  The movie really started getting good for me when we are first introduced to Dr. Shirley.  I also don't necessarily love the title.  The Green Book is something that appears in the movie a couple of times but didn't have the largest significance and didn't really have anything to do with the message they were going for.  Despite that this movie is very good and I do feel it deserved the Oscar for Best Picture.

Tony Lip is an Italian-American bouncer tasked with the job of driving a world-class Black pianist, on a concert tour from Manhattan to the Deep South in 1962. Their differences are put aside as they fight prejudice, racism and some very dangerous situations while trying to make it to each venue on time.

I'd heard rumblings from people, griping that some of the details may have been altered from the facts, that some events might have been slightly changed. And also, there was some talk that they made the white guy a bit more of a hero than he was in real life.

Well, to be honest, for me, even if they did make those changes, I really didn't see that sort of 'white-washing' in this movie.

Set in 1962, a classically-trained black pianist hires a white Italian from the Bronx to be his driver, and personal assistant during a concert tour of the deep south. Knowing there would be some trouble while dealing with racial tensions during the pre-civil rights era south, Dr. Don Shirley (Mahershala Ali) hires Tony Vallelonga (Viggo Mortensen) to help navigate these tough waters.

Right from the outset, we see these two couldn't be more different. Tony is a guy living on the periphery of organized crime in the Bronx, working at the Copacabana, and Dr. Shirley lives above a concert hall in a luxury apartment filled with statues, elephant tusks, and artwork from around the world.

Now we've all seen movies like this before, and we know where the story is probably going to take us. We will head to the deep south, where Shirley will encounter racism, and Tony will be the hired muscle to help him through it. And they'll both learn a little something about each other along the way.

But there were a few things that make this movie extra special.

1) Usually in movies featuring the black/white dynamic, it's the white guy who is the 'educated' one, and it's up to the black guy to show him just how uncool he is (Kevin Hart, I'm talking to you)...but in this movie, it was the other way around. It was the black character who is smarter, more refined, more learned, and has a lot to teach Tony about the world. So that was a nice change of pace.

It was also nice to see the two characters slowly embrace their differences. At first, Tony has the standard pushback. "Ehhh, I don't need nobody to tell me how to use a napkin". But he soon sees that maybe he has a little room to grow and improve. Same goes for Dr. Shirley. At first, he sees the guy in the driver's seat as this uncouth baboon, worthy of little more than snark and dismay, but ultimately there's something he could learn from him too.

2) The performace of Mahershala Ali was something very special. The character of Dr. Shirley could have easily been a one-dimensional snob that goes nowhere fast...but there's an underlying fear and scared little child just under the surface of Ali's performance. He's someone who has lived on the edges of both the black and white world throughout his entire life. We also learn midway through that he's gay, so he's struggled in that world as well.

He has a brilliant line midway through the movie when Tony mocks his aloofness and says, "hey I'm blacker than YOU!" Dr. Shirley gets out of the car in an utter downpour and yells, "So if I'm not black enough, and if I'm not white enough, and if I'm not man enough, then tell me Tony, what am I?!"

Clearly Shirley has been dealing with this conundrum his entire life, but he had never shown that vulnerability before. He is someone who seems to have it all figured out, but in reality, he's confused and alone. It was a true moment of revelation, and something you don't normally see in movies like this. Usually it's just wacky comic mayhem where the uptight character tries on silly clothes, some stupid hillbillies chasin' em in a truck, and then roll the end credits. Ali gave the charater of Dr. Shirley some serious depth and pathos I was definitely not expecting.

3) Viggo Mortensen, as usual, was brilliant as well. He could have easily just done a DeNiro/Danza impersonation and "hey oh, oh, eyyyd" is way through this character, but he really was a joy to behold. Not only does he have some great laugh lines as the street-wise gambino, but you see his slow evolution from a guy who's just about as racist as the Southern hicks they come across, to seeing Dr. Shirley as who he is. A man. But never in a schmaltzy, schticky way.

And in regards to him being the 'hero'....he was hardly a hero. His job was to protect Dr. Shirley in the south (because hey, a black man traveling alone in the deep south in the 60s, no matter how heroic he wanted to be, would be up against impossible odds, so Dr. Shirley did indeed need some help.) But even then, Tony did as little as possible through a good chunk of the movie to "help" Dr. Shirley. He 'tolerated' him for most of the time, and their friendship slowly developed, but was never over the top or 'heroic". It was very subtle, and for that, I was grateful. I didn't need to be hit over the head with a message, or big crisis-fueled revelations. Watching these two characters grow to like each other, either through letter writing, listening to Little Richard, or the joys of eating fried chicken with your fingers... was a joy.

There weren't any real surprises in this movie, just a good story, VERY well told.

I'd love for this to win the Best Picture as it was easily my favorite movie of the nominees...but I don't think it will.

But then again, stories like this aren't told for awards. They are told to make us smile, make us think, and make us better people.

And Green Book accomplishes all three.

Green Book is an highly enjoyable movie but it lacks originality. Indeed I think of it like the "younger cousin" of ‘The Untouchables', a French film from 2011 because they have too many similarities. The story about two different men who meet each other and grow thanks to this encounter is the same, only planted in a different environment, and also the alternation between humor and touching moment is very similar. ‘The Untouchables' was truly a great movie and so is this one; if you didn't saw the French one you will probably be surprised by Green Book, if you did you will like it but with the feeling of "I've already seen it"...

Green Book winning Best Picture is a tragedy I'll never forget. When you think about the fact that this lost to Roma, is in the same club as films like Moonlight and even fared better than La La Land, Arrival and so many other deserving films, I'm only reminded of just how much of a joke "award seasons" can really be.

I've read a lot of other reviews and it seems that a lot of people loved the feel-good moments. Well, good for you, but unfortunately I didn't think much of it was comedic or touching at all. Yet whatever else you may argue, you cannot tell me you didn't cringe a single bit watching that fried chicken scene. I mean, in the trailer it didn't seem that bad, but then you just get Viggo Mortensen forcing Mahershala Ali repeatedly as if the cool kid is being pressured to not look "foolish". What could have been decent and respectful comedy turned into something so uncomfortable for which Peter Farrelly should be utterly ashamed of. The worst part was that he then tells him he's not black enough? That turned my discomfort into anger. WTF were the writers thinking? 

Personally, I want to make it clear that I'm the kind of guy who can forgive white-savior tropes where the film is well-written, filled with great performances, and yet still most importantly, doesn't cross the line. The Help and Hidden Figures are two examples of white-savior tropes which at least for me, managed to entertain and yet never went the offensive route. But this movie is just a whole different ball game. It's not only crossed the line but also manages to be a structural and technical mess. The first 30 minutes are really near useless,  and the story bumps around so many things to make it sound more complicated. It was like they were running through a checklist of themes they had to cover in different sections of the film to make it Oscar-worthy. There's black identity, isolation, dignity and social status, and then that ONE standalone scene on sexual identity, but they never come together under the hands of a director with no central vision. So what does he do to cover up his weaknesses? He puts together that touching ending to make us feel all good inside as we walk out the theater. The result is that even Mortensen and Ali's great performances were in my opinion heavily diminished to characters with character developments so misfired, unengaging and inconsistent.

I'm not the most eloquent person, but I just needed some sort of medium to express my anger that such a film got made in the first place, and so I hope you get my point!

Totally unenlightening, unless you never knew about Italian-American stereotypes. It's an agreeable feel-good movie that tries to look past the heavier context and focus on the relationships and self-acceptance found in each character. The story is delivered with some exceptional cinematography and unforgettable chemistry. However, the fact that it won Best Picture in 2018 over more original movies is not something I would expect, as the story did not leave a lasting impression like other nominees in the category. While it doesn't offer up any real solutions for racial equality, Green Book still fits the bill for a solid family night movie. It's a story that is sure to entertain, even if it is just to sit back, smile, and watch an astounding performance of two grown men throwing chicken bones out of a moving car together.

Green Book is an excellent film. It is about a working-class Italian-American bouncer who becomes the driver of an African-American classical pianist on a tour of venues through the 1960s American South. Viggo Mortensen and Marshershala Ali give fantastic performances. The script is well written. Peter Farrelly did a great job directing this movie. I enjoyed watching this motion picture because of the humor and drama. Green Book is a must see.

I don't get the backlash for Green Book ever since it won Best Picture at the Oscars. I would have voted for BlacKkKlansman, but I thought Green Book was a very nice film with a witty, yet impactful screenplay, and two actors that work very well off each other.

Strengths: One thing seems to carry this film above all else. The acting. Mahershala Ali (Don Shirley) and Viggo Mortensen (Frank Vallelonga) are both phenomenal. Their chemistry shines in each scene. There are times where they're just talking and you're captivated or caught smiling because of how well it all works. You like both guys. Their differences are very fun. Don is the one who is well read and has manners, yet he's looked down upon because of his race and Frank is kind of in the opposite boat. I also enjoyed Linda Cardellini (Dolores Vallelonga) in her smaller supporting role. The writing is very well done, as the characters are given strong moments to let their personalities shine and the dialogue is natural and sharp. There's a lot of charm to almost everything that happens.

Weaknesses: There are some pacing issues here. Some scenes feel like they go on a bit long and others seem like they aren't needed. This could've been cut down to about 110 minutes and probably been tighter. I'm not big on Peter Farrelly as a director. None of his work has ever impressed me and I don't think he did anything to stand out in this one. It's shot in such a generic fashion that it's kind of just there.

Overall: Should this have won Best Picture? No. Is it still a good movie? Absolutely. The writing is solid and I think the acting is fantastic, making for an enjoyable time.

A bouncer-like Italian in New York is out of jobs. A nice, but simple fella and a true family man. He got a lovely wife and some kids and need a new steady income and luckily for Tony a very gifted pianist is in need of a tour driver.

Dr. Donald Shirley is quite the opposite. A loner, that's got a way with both words and manners as well as his piano skills. Back in the 1960's color was still a big matter in the US, and on this journey the two differently colored men get a taste of that.

This is a layered but extremely well directed and superbly written film. It's about differences, loneliness, hate, love, fried chicken, standing up for eachother and change, but most importantly it's about friendship.

It's cast is brilliant ant the performances are ace. This is a ride that never brings dull or unneeded moments and it's got that bright comedy tones all over and manage to never get silly or dumb. Sure, it's a bit oversentimental and easy to predict, but it works. Think of "The Intouchables" meeting "Driving Miss Daisy" or something. This is fun, this is safe, this is entertaining.

I don't get the hate here. Sure, it's a bit controversial with the racial matter stuff, but I find it both important and pretty believeable. One of the better Oscar winners or Oscar nominated films of the year for me. It caught my interest fast and kept me glued, with smiles, laughs and tears all over my face.

There was shock and outrage when this admittedly retrograde film took home the Best Picture statuette against more interesting, original and current films like Roma (2018) and The Favorite (2018). Particularly shocking is the fact that the film's director is Peter Farrelly, best known for gross-out comedies like Kingpin (1996) and The Three Stooges (2012), not exactly a Daldry or a Frears. Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali had proven themselves to be Academy favorites in the past, Mortensen has received multiple nominations whilst Ali won for his work in 2016's Moonlight, but their pairing seemed unlikely. Despite all of this and early predictions that Roma would take the prize Green Book triumphed.

Tony "the lip" Vallellonga, Viggo Mortensen, is a racist Italian-American in 1950s New York City who is encouraged to question his prejudices when he begins working for educated African-American pianist Don Shirley, Mahershala Ali. Shirley needs a driver and bodyguard as he tours the Southern United States and he has been told that Vallellonga is the man for the job. Both will overcome their preconceptions of one another and learn a little something about themselves as they take a comedic road trip through a dangerous part of America. 

I quite liked the film, it was funny and charming and the performances of Mortensen, Ali and Linda Cardellini as Mrs. Vallellonga were very good but would I call it better than The Favorite? Well no. It's perfectly OK but it does employ the white savior trope that I hoped we had moved beyond with films like Moonlight (2016) and in the same year If Beale Street Could Talk (2018). It makes you question the demographic makeup of the Academy when a film like this, which would have been illuminating to some members of society in the late 1960s but 50 years later if you can't acknowledge that African-Americans have just as much to offer as white people you are racist not uninformed. It's nice that the highly accomplished actress Octavia Spencer is now an Academy award winning producer but it's saddening that this and The Help (2011), a worse white savior trope movie, are the films that she has been most rewarded for. 

In short: this is a film that you don't really have to see, much like Darkest Hour (2017) just watching the trailer allows you to understand what the whole two hours will be like. Unless you're a Cardellini fan you can stay away.

Some of the gags work really well with the fried chicken scene and the dropping of the cup eliciting a half smile but some of them fall flat like the pronunciation of Vallellonga gag, is it really that hard to pronounce? The gag that really worked for me was the card writing gag as we see Shirley composing romantic letters for Mrs. Vallellonga that she and her friends eagerly await. The card that means the most to her is the one written by her husband as he starts the letter with "You remind me of a big house" but follows this with "Where the lights are always on and everybody is happy inside." His writing of this and her delighted response are very sweet and touching and although it is a very heavy-handed touch, like much of this film, it feels more genuine than most of the film.

Linda Cardellini is quite lovely in this film as the reasonable wife who endeavors to bring her husband and Shirley closer together. She has a warmth and a sensibility to her that matches the description of the character and you are often left wondering how Vallellonga nabbed such a wonderful woman. Much like in The Founder (2016), a much better film, she is always a bright spot when she appears on screen and her sparing use leaves you wanting more of her. It is such a shame that the Daddy's Home franchise has become her meal ticket because she has real dramatic abilities and they would be put to use in better films.

This was not the best film of 2018 and I would not have even nominated it for Best Picture but of the nominated films I would have given the award to Roma because it is a technical marvel. Hopefully we can leave this sort of film behind and reward more interesting fare in the future.
