While Green Book may appear to be simple Oscar bait aimed at older demographics, I can assure you that this is not the case.  The plot gets started when an Italian Mob-adjacent, low-level bouncer finds himself out of work when the Copacabana club he works at closes down for a couple of months.  (Yes, the same Copacabana from that famous tracking shot in Goodfellas.)  Not wanting to become a mob soldier, he takes a job for distinguished African-American concert pianist, Don Shirley.  He is to drive Shirley across the Deep South in a Cadillac DeVille, make sure that he stays in "Colored" friendly establishments, and to act as his bodyguard.  This road trip goes about as well as you'd expect.  Tony's coarse and boorish demeanor irritate Shirley, and Tony asserts that Shirley is detached from his "own people."  Over time, Don's erudite language and writing acumen rubs off on his driver, while Tony get his employer to lighten up and stand up for himself.  

Green Book could be described as Driving Miss Daisy for Men, but it's a bit more than that, with a fair amount of punch and tense moments.  It's also pretty fuckin funny.  Yeah, no shit I was laughing my ass off the entire time, as was the rest of the audience.  Most of which comes from the ridiculous conversations between our low-level mobster and his sophisticated, but out of place companion, while trying not to get murdered in Hickville.  And this comes down to performances.  Mahershala Ali is on fire these days, and his work here is no exception.  While it would seem that he is relegated to the "straight man" of the story, it's more that he's the anchor that holds it together.  He has plenty of moments of levity and it was interesting to watch his emotional progress through the film.  Viggo Mortensen is a riot and while his character does border on tri-state area Italian stereotypes, it works.  Mortensen has amazing comedic timing and I enjoyed every minute of it.  Peter Farrelly does a competent job telling this story, which is surprising as he mostly did low brow comedies before this.  As for the controversy surrounding Green Book, no I don't feel that this classifies as a "white savior" film.  They save each other, as saccharine as that sounds.  It's more of an arthouse road trip picture than anything else.  I don't know if it handles race in the best manner, but it doesn't make too many missteps.  One scene did annoy me, in which both characters are screaming at each other in the rain.  (It's almost a parody of Oscar clip nonsense.)  Both main characters are based on real people, as Tony Lip would later have small roles in The Godfather, Goodfellas, and The Sopranos.  Don Shirley really was a world renowned classical and jazz pianist, though it has been disputed how close these two really were.  In either case Green Book is an enjoyable watch for just about anybody, and while it's not perfect, it's pretty damn good.

Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali deliver fantastic performances in "Green Book", a deeply moving film about the friendship between a black pianist and Italian-American driver. Director Peter Farrelly's latest film tells a remarkable true story that has to be seen to be believed. With the help of a sharp script and terrific performances from the leading stars, director Peter Farrelly manages to do justice to a true story. At the center of it all are Viggo Mortenson and Mahershala Ali, who make for a pair of likeable leads. Mortenson is terrific in the role of a clumsy yet caring driver, while Ali brings nuance and depth to the role of the African-American pianist. Both these actors deliver performances that will surely not be forgotten come awards season. Although it suffers slightly from a lengthy running time, "Green Book" is a must-see this holiday season. Stories like this don't come along often, but on those rare occasions that they do it's a cause for celebration.

On it's surface, Green Book seems to be a your typical 'after school special', early 60's racism was bad especially in the South, narrative.  With most critics focusing on how the racial issues are handled, and with others focused on winning the 'virtue signaling' championship (Richard Brody, et al). However, the more important theme to the story is isolation. Isolation stemming from the case that piano virtuoso, Don Shirley, is also gay.

This revelation comes to light when Don Shirley's driver, Tony Lip, finds Don being arrested at a YMCA shower sitting naked with a White man by his side.  Tony bribes the cops and points out the obvious life shaping fact to Don, that if this gets out, it could ruin his career.

This fact answers many questions. Like in one previous scene, Tony rescues Don getting beat up at a White bar.  Which, on it's face, seems like Don was maybe flouting convention and trying out a Rosa Parks moment. But, as Tony gets Don out of the jam, he asks why he came to that bar to drink when normally he drinks alone at his apartment.  The subsequent YMCA scene answers that.  He's attracted to White men and that's why he went to a White bar.  In contrast, this happens immediately after Don rejects an invitation to play backyard games with his Black neighbors at his hotel.

It becomes apparent that the discrimination Don Shirley receives from White society as a Black man is not as severe as the rejection and isolation he feels from the Black community as a Gay man. 

This also answers what Shirley means when he says he has not been able to keep a relationship with his 'brother'.  A line that was a point of contention with Don Shirley's real family who said they were always close with Don. Not realizing the line was a euphemism for Don's ex-boyfriend or hypothetical boyfriend, juxtaposed with a conversation about Tony's relationship with his wife. 

This gave Don something else he had in common with Tony.  They both had to be 'bullshit artists' even if for different reasons.

The isolation Shirley feels is also experienced at a milder level byTony.  Hired to be a driver for two months.  Cut off from his family and friends with a poor ability to communicate with his wife through letters.  And also isolated from conversation with Don on their long drives between gigs.

That isolation is broken down when Don begins to help Tony write those letters to his wife in a more poetic fashion.  Almost like Don was writing a letter to a hypothetical boyfriend he would never be able to realize.
If not the best movie in the last decade certainly a top contender for best picture of the year.  Restored all faith in mankind.......wonderful.

Green Book plays like a twenty-first century rendition of Driving Miss Daisy, a well-meaning and relatively gentle movie about race relations where a prejudiced white person comes about thanks to their firsthand friendship with an African-American male. It's reportedly inspired by the true story of Tony Lip (Viggo Mortensen), a nightclub bouncer, driving around a famed pianist, Dr. Don Shirley (Mahershala Ali), as he performed throughout the South in 1962. The best part of the movie is the character interaction between this odd couple, and you'll get plenty of it too. The actors burrow into their very distinctly conflicting characters, so it's a natural pleasure to watch them eventually bond and learn from one another. This is the kind of racism that doesn't make people feel too uncomfortable, and you could say that about the film as a whole. It's a bit safe and has its intentions set on being a big, inclusive crowd-pleaser, and it plays like one. There are moments to make you laugh, moments to make you cheer, and moments to make you tear up. Morstensen and Ali are terrific together and find dignity and humanity in characters that could have easily become one-note stereotypes. The more we learn about Dr. Shirley the more interesting he becomes, a man used to feeling like an outsider no matter the company he keeps. Watching the two men grow and open up to one another can be heartwarming and deeply satisfying. Remarkably, the film is directed and co-written by one half of the Farrelly brothers, the pair responsible for ribald comedies like There's Something About Mary and Dumb and Dumber. It's an easy movie to fall for, with its winning formula and enjoyable actors, but there's a little nagging concern I have that Green Book is too safe, too straight, and too pat in its life lessons. Despite its Best Picture win, it's not like Driving Miss Daisy has any lasting cultural impression, and I wonder if maybe Green Book is destined for the same. Still, the acting and writing is enough to bring a smile to your face and remind one's self about the power of kindness.

There isn't a person you wouldn't love if you could read their story. I tend to try and not speak in absolutes and there may or may not be some exceptions to this rule, but the point is an obvious one: all the races and people with different sexual orientations or different religious beliefs can get along once we really get to know one another; that we're not really all that different after all. That's all well and good, but it's also a tried and true formula that at least one Hollywood production trots out every awards season to try and make us all feel better about ourselves. One might think, given the current cultural climate, that any movie attempting to bring people together might immediately be dismissed as one party's agenda to corrupt another into actually having a conversation with a person of opposing views, but maybe that's ultimately why Green Book feels so good right now and ironically, so needed. There isn't a damn thing here you haven't heard or seen before and director Peter Farrelly (one half of the brother directing duo who brought us comedy classics like Dumb & Dumber and There's Something About Mary, but also brought us Dumb & Dumber To and The Heartbreak Kid) directs with the eye of about as mainstream a filmmaker as it gets meaning there is nothing glaringly unique or interesting about the way in which he captures these events, but this does mean it will undoubtedly speak to a very large audience. There was some slight hope that Farrelly might utilize his experience in his years of making broad studio comedies to infuse the many predictable formulas this movie utilizes with a more striking tone or presence, but while taking on a project like this might have been a bold thing for the filmmaker to do given his past credits he alas decides to do nothing bold in the execution of this change in pace, but instead plays it right down the middle. Fortunately for Farrelly, the story has such a great inherent hook and given he's hired two more than capable talents to lead his film it hardly matters how he's saying what he wants to say as long as it's competent enough to capture how Mahershala Ali and Viggo Mortensen are saying what they want to say. It's largely through these two performers that Green Book transcends the calculations of a movie such as itself, eclipsing every predictable note it plays that could have so easily rung false to become something genuinely endearing; a true crowd-pleaser in the least cynical and most delightful of ways.

This is a good but more so an important film. The critics who didnt like it did so because it wrecked their simplistic, polarizing world view. It wrecks the labels and stereotypes they rely on to define people, motives, our past, and our current political climate. This film takes class, race, educated, and non educated, and flips them upside down from the traditional sense, then smashes them together. What emerges, even as 1960s society tries to box the characters in, is a poignant realization of the futility in identifying people as a group. That we are all individuals first. Flawed, misconstrued, confused, imperfect, yet also caring, compassionate, talented, and well meaning. Mortensen and Ali are both excellent and deliver outstanding performances as two men from different sides of the tracks who, according to 60ssociety, should never get along or form a bond. But they dont get sucked into that divisive abyss and instead judge each other through their own interactions. This film has humor, drama, and a nice blend of non preachy realism that makes you empathize and identify with the characters without feeling like you're being lectured to. Highly recommended, for sure.

Update: I like it but something is off. New Grade: A- Green Book Review: Green Book is inspired by the true friendship of Tony Lip (Viggo Mortensen), a working class Italian-American bouncer and Dr. Don Shirley (Mahershala Ali), an African-American pianist, as Tony Lip drives Dr. Shirley on his venue tour in the 1960s in the southern states. This is the movie, other than A Star is Born, that has been getting the biggest Oscar buzz this season. It seemed like an interesting plot and looked really good. I’ve given out 4 A+ scores this year, one being for the miniseries Sharp Objects, and I’m happy to say Green Book joins that group. I loved every minute of this movie! The story by Peter Farrelly was so good. Definitely will get a nomination for Best Original Screenplay, though I do think Roma will end up winning it. The dialogue worked. The pacing was good. There was just so much emotion put into this. As the tour gets deeper into the South, Dr. Shirley experiences more racism and you just had no words to describe all of the emotion and feelings put into those scenes. The performances by the two actors are the best of all year. Viggo Mortensen will win Best Actor. His portrayal of Tony Lip was amazing. His best performance yet. He was a lovable character. And it’s a character that has flaws and it’s acknowledged throughout and Viggo knew how to do that. Mahershala Ali will for sure win his second Oscar, first for playing Juan in Moonlight, playing Dr. Shirley. This is his best role to date. There were scenes that made me laugh and some bringing tears. This is a lock for Best Supporting Actor. I loved Linda Cardellini as Delores but I don’t think she’ll be recognized for her role. Peter Farrelly’s direction was great. He has made some horrendous films in the past, one being Movie 43, but he did very well and could get a nomination for Best Director, probably won’t win however. The score by Kris Bowers was very good. It was a mix of classical music that Dr. Shirley played and 60s jazz. I think he’ll get a nomination for Best Original Score. Not too many scores have been released for upcoming films so it’s hard to tell what he’s up against though there are a few from earlier this year that could get nominated. The cinematography was good but not good enough for the nomination. In all honesty, so far this is the film that I think will win Best Picture at the Oscars 2019 (I will put my top 10 Best Picture Predictions below). It had so much to say and I think it’s a film everyone should see. It’s relevant and I will say my favorite Christmas movie to date. I was disappointed to see that it didn’t make too much at the box office yet, only making 14.0 million and only #10 at the the top box office for its second week into its release. It was promoted at theaters but not many theaters got it. I had to go all the way to Appleton to see it and it was in a small theater that was packed. I was happy to see how many people went to see it. Overall you should see the movie when you get the chance. I don’t think you could hate it. My Grade: A+ My Oscar 2019 Best Picture Predictions so far (they’re pretty close to the Gold Derby Predictions): 1. Green Book 2. Roma 3. A Star is Born 4. If Beale Street Could Talk 5. The Favourite 6. Vice 7. BlacKkKlansman 8. First Man 9. Black Panther (it’s really getting a lot of buzz) 10. Can You Ever Forgive Me?

I hate being lectured by Hollywood about race, so I had to be dragged to see this film. It did a decent job of not crossing the fine line between cliché and freshness. Besides two Oscar-worthy lead actor performances this script handled the issue of race effectively without being overbearing. Based on a true story, it is more about a great friendship about personal growth and respect than anything else. Definitely one of the best films of 2018.

The last time I saw Viggo Mortensen was an Oscar and otherwise buzz-worthy performance in an indy -flick, Captain Fantastic (2016). He is back to take another grab at the statuette along with co-star Mahershala Ali. Anyone who knows me and this film will not  be surprised that I find this a perfect film. The story of a working class bouncer-type driving an erudite concert pianist around to performances in the American deep South in the early 1960s, seem increasingly Oscar-baity.  It is constructed and hits all the story telling rhythm notes one expects. Playing Tony Lip Vallenlogna, Mortensen makes me believe that he is s glutinous schlub. His corpulence is matched by a new level of slender on the part of  Ali. They are the new Odd Couple.  The organic quality of the growth of their mutual admiration and friendship is credible and engaging. For me the quality of this movie comes down to the fear in Dr. Don Shirley, the fear that Tony will leave him to face this situation alone. One can argue that this well-to-do well-educated black man oddly puts too much control in the hands of this white man, thereby undercutting a part of the message. If the message is friendship, then maybe letting go is the point. We find that Dr. Don Shirley's mission, his karma yoga, is to change hearts and mind in defying preconceived notions of the value of who or what he was, by being present.  The hearts he changes here are chiefly Tony's and his own. The performances are great. Linda Cardellini also turns in a strong performance as the wife of Tony Lip. The score is good. The cinematography is excellent.  The art direction is perfect. This movie is not a preachy baseball bat. Did I mention this is a story based on real people and a real relationship? This one is as good as a movie gets without bringing me to tears.

Usually, when a film is made and has very little depth in terms of storytelling, it would be forgotten about, but if you have a unique take on a specific story and the point of the movie is to keep it simple and explore only one facet of history. Personally, I prefer when stories are a little more fleshed out, but I also believe this simple story in Green Book is one of the best films of 2018. This is a movie that cares about its characters first and foremost and we donâ(TM)t see many of those films hitting the big screen very often, so this was a pleasant surprise. Although thereâ(TM)s not much meat to the story (which may bore some viewers), I found Green Book to be a fantastic piece of filmmaking.

Fired from the downtown club and forced to take any job he can in order to support his family, Tony Lip (Viggo Mortensen) decides to take on the role of driving pianist Dr. Don Shirley (Mahershala Ali) across the South, as he and his band perform for audiences. With the inclusion of the fact that Don is an African-American man in the 1960s and Tony being an Italian-American, many racial occurrences arise for these two. Being an unlikely pairing for that particular decade, these characters needed to be like-able and completely fleshed out in order for this film to work and those two aspects were absolutely astoundingly well-done in my opinion. This also stems from a particularly great turn by director Peter Farrelly.

Although his earlier work on films like Dumb and Dumber and Thereâ(TM)s Something About Mary are very commendable outings, his recent comedies havenâ(TM)t exactly struck gold. Having his last few films being Dumb and Dumber To, Hall Pass, and The Heartbreak Kid, I was very worried about him taking on a more dramatic film. After watching this film, I felt ridiculous even thinking that, because not only has he shown maturity as a director this time around, but also completely understood how to blend his sense of humour with a more meaningful premise. If he sticks with this style of filmmaking, I can definitely see his name in the public eye more often in the coming years. The way he handles his performers here was truly something special.

As I said, it truly is the character arcs that carry this film and without amazing performances, this movie wouldâ(TM)ve been forgotten. Mortensen and Ali both give their all in these roles and it shows. There wasnâ(TM)t a single moment where I found myself scratching my head or not believing a decision they made or line of dialogue they spoke. In the vein of films like Driving Miss Daisy or even Before Sunrise, the conversations are the reason this film doesnâ(TM)t feel slow. Thereâ(TM)s hardly a single exciting scene and the movie clocks in at nearly 140 minutes. Thatâ(TM)s when you know the dialogue has been written very well by the trio in Nick Vallelonga, Brian Hayes Currie, and Peter Farrelly.

In the end, I canâ(TM)t see everyone loving this film, due to the slow pace it has, but itâ(TM)s a breezy crowd-pleaser nonetheless. This movie has been generating major awards consideration and I think it deserves every bit of it and then some. I loved my experience watching this movie and I canâ(TM)t wait to revisit it and take this journey with these characters again. Funny, sad, and heartwarming, Green Book easily earns the title of being one of the best feel-good movies in recent memory (at least to me). I loved this movie and I canâ(TM)t recommend it enough.

Race relations.  This is about a piano virtuoso savant, Dr. Don Shirley (Mahershala Ali).  He is doing a concert tour of the Deep South and needs someone who can serve both as a driver and as protection.  Enter Tony "Lip" Vallelonga (Viggo Mortensen).  Now the buzz on this one has been pretty high, so I've been getting increasingly more and more excited for Green Book.  The trailers looked pretty damn good, and being that this headlines two acting heavyweights in Ali and Mortensen, I walked into this expecting one of the best movies of the 2018.  Well, I will go ahead and break the ice to let you know that I was not disappointed in the slightest by this.  Now what is easily the most surprising thing about this film is that it is directed by Peter Farrelly.  Yes, that is one half of the Farrelly brothers who are better known for There's Something About Mary, Dumb and Dumber and Shallow Hal.  Not that those movies don't have their audience, but to suddenly switch it up and helm an Oscar contender is the sort of drastic change that could give someone whiplash.  And yes, you better believe that this is going to at the very least get a ton of nominations this award season; I would be shocked if this got any less than four nominations from the Academy, and they would be completely well founded.  What you may not realize from watching previews is the extent of how funny this is.  It is an odd couple road trip movie when you break it down to basics, but what really makes this work as well as it does is the chemistry shared by Ali and Mortensen.  They are coming from polar opposites on the culture spectrum, and being that they are forced to spend so much time with one another, they have no choice but to meet each other in the middle.  Green Book works on a number of different levels, so of course you should go out of your way to see it.  It works as a biography, giving you insight into the lives of these gentlemen.  It works as a comedy, giving you a big belly laugh every ten minutes or so.  It works as a social commentary, as a period piece and even as a feel-good movie that will almost assuredly be the high point of your day.  I don't really have much to complain about, and if I did, it would be small nitpicks.  Go watch and support this movie.
Best movie I’ve seen in s long time !!! Excellent performance from all!!!

Though its softened edges and cautious approach might irk some of the more discerning viewers in the audience, its "Green Book's" benevolent nature and engaging thematic material that should be commended above all. Generally more of a comedic filmmaker, director Peter Farrelly handles the story behind Don Shirley and Tony Vallelonga's true-to-life friendship with a surprising patience and care, ultimately lending a tremendously feel-good experience. Spearhead all of that with some unsurprisingly magnificent performance work from both Mahershala Ali and Viggo Mortensen, and you've got yourself one of the better movies of the year.
very good....thought it had empty scenes at times

I'd first seen the trailer for this back in mid-October on the new Halloween movie of all things. I had not heard anything about it prior so that got it on my radar. I noticed there was not a lot of attention put on the director, which if you look up who it is, you will be totally shocked! If this is how he can handle a drama, I think he has found a new path for the future. For the movie itself, I thought it was excellent. I've seen some reviews say if you are expecting something more along the lines of Driving Miss Daisy as opposed to Selma, you won't set yourself up for any disappointments. I guess that could be true on how to view this. Does it pay a lot of attention to what is going on in the country at this time? No. I don't think that should be strikes against the quality of this movie because it does not veer into those territories. It focuses more on the relationship of these two characters, their encounters and how they deal with them and each other. The two characters on their journey are the story and how they help each other evolve and broaden their own tolerances and understanding of the world (and each other). In the beginning, it starts out as a business relationship and as the friendship builds, you root for them to safely get out of circumstances and locations. The friendship peaks as they get to some of the most dangerous areas along the path. I think there is an increased tension that an audience member feels as you hope they can take care of each other and eventually make a safe return home. There is a surprising amount of humor that makes both characters all the more likeable. It is very much a fish out of water story on numerous levels ... the two characters who, at first, don't relate to each other but then take a journey together into an area that neither relates to. I think this movie will sneak in and out of theaters in a few weeks but just as nominations are announced (and it gets a few), it will be right about the time of the DVD/Blu-ray release. I think it will then get the attention it deserves.

'Green Book' barrels past some initial hokeyness to take us on a poignant journey through the deep south ... and into the heart of America's persistent deficiency in overcoming racial inequality.

Mahershala Ali and Viggo Mortensen both disappear into their roles as only actors of their caliber can, making every scene so captivating that the movie's 130-minute run time feels half as long.  

There's plenty of contemplation and outrage to go around.  However, it's the genuine laughs that truly round out the film, providing a full range of delightful (and sometimes dizzying) emotions that quickly come and pass like mile markers on the side of a highway.
Great show!  Everyone must see this movie, particularly in this agree of racial conflict.

And a very pleasing ending as well. A Must See in my "Book"

A superb fact-based road trip buddy film featuring two of the unlikeliest of travel companions. This tale of an African-American pianist and his New York Italian driver on a concert tour of the American South in 1962 hits all the right notes without belaboring its message while effectively capturing the unusual friendship that grows between the film's two protagonists. Excellent performances by Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali are punctuated by a script that's full of laughs, poignancy and heart. An underrated gem that deserves high marks and well-earned accolades.

One of the best movies I have seen this year, and a great History lesson as well!

DRIVING ME CRAZY - My Review of GREEN BOOK (3 Stars)

How many times have you heard people say, "They don't make 'em like they used to"?  In the case of GREEN BOOK, a classically made, impeccably performed and written film, I wondered to myself, "Should they?".  Sometimes it's difficult to separate a film from the time in which it's been made, and for me, we have what amounts to a pleasant yet reductive film which my 1989 self would have enjoyed a whole lot more than I did in 2018.  In actuality, I found DRIVING MISS DAISY pretty insufferable even back then, so maybe I've always had a problem with racism filtered through a white perspective.

GREEN BOOK, inspired by a true story, tells the tale of a vulgar Italian bouncer named Tony "Lip" Vallelonga (Viggo Mortensen) who, in 1962, gets hired by Dr. Don Shirley (Maershala Ali), an effete, accomplished pianist who lives above Carnegie Hall, to drive him around the country on a two month national tour, protecting him from the dangers of the racist South.  Their unlikely friendship informs this lightly comedic, heartwarming tale.  

Director Peter Farrelly (THERE'S SOMETHING ABOUT MARY), who co-wrote the script with Brian Hayes Currie and Tony's real life son Nick Vallelonga employs slick, classic filmmaking style where the images look pretty and the pace keeps the beautifully delineated script humming along for its entire run.  The jokes land, the character development feels refined and earned, the lump hits the throat in the third act just where intended, but the entire approach feels wrong.  

In a year in which the black experience has seen a creative renaissance with such films as BLACKKKLANSMAN, SORRY TO BOTHER YOU, and IF BEALE STREET COULD TALK, to name a few, GREEN BOOK feels safe.  In the past, racism needed a white perspective with such films as IN THE HEAT OF THE NIGHT, CRY FREEDOM, and MISSISSIPPI BURNING.  Through that lens, filmgoers could look at the issue as something in the past, allowing the sympathetic character to serve as their own window into this world.  Tony's wife Dolores (a terrific Linda Cardellini) fills that role in GREEN BOOK.  We can all say, "That would have been me!"  It offers the viewer a safety net in order to make the horrors of racism more palatable.  As someone who grew up in a fairly racist small town in Ohio, it was ugly and wrong and stupid.  It didn't feel better that there were nice people who meant well when the systemic problem overrode all of that.  I'll never forget the time one of my high school teachers stood up in front of the classroom and said she would never hire a black person for a job that a white person could do.  Everyone stayed silent, although I'm proud to say at a later time, I used her words against her.  The fact that she didn't lose her job proved that good intentions meant nothing in a society built on allowing such racism.  

I'm not saying the story of GREEN BOOK shouldn't be told.  It truly means well.  Mortensen and Ali invest their characters with a tremendous amount of heart, both maintaining dramatic tension throughout.  A case can be made, however, that at its core, the film is a populist Christmas movie in which a tight Yule hug can save the world.  In 2018, at a time when the flames of racism have been fanned by a President keen on dividing a nation, GREEN BOOK would have benefited by telling its story entirely from Don Shirley's point of view.  Instead of what amounts to an unusual buddy movie, how about putting us in that back seat along with Shirley and digging into his inner life?  His exterior gets a lot of traction with his hand gestures, his beatific smile every time he finishes one of his glorious numbers, and his snobby leers at Tony's lack of culture and class.  Because we spend more time in Tony's shoes, we lose Don's key decision-making points.  Two examples would be when Tony has to come rescue Don from two perilous events.  Had we stuck with Shirley when he initiated these moments, we would have felt his fear, his naiveté, and his humiliation that much more.  

I applaud the fact that this film shows a different type of black experience with the roles reversed from what we've grown accustomed to seeing.  It would have had so much more power, however, had it stayed strictly with Shirley and let us feel what it truly was like to sit in the backseat with a man-child at the wheel, with danger lurking around every corner, and with feelings of alienation within his own community.  Shirley's "otherness", which I won't spoil here, gets addressed and dismissed with a handful of lines.  I would have loved to have seen what a filmmaker like Dee Rees would have done with it, since MUDBOUND perfectly addressed both a white and black perspective so well.  The joy of Farrelly getting to make a film unlike anything he's done before and in a style he's clearly dreamed of attempting for so long gets overshadowed by the fact that GREEN BOOK, more than anything else, feels like a very nice, easily digestible missed opportunity.

Embarking on a journey through segregationist America at a time when overt racism and stereotypes were ruggedly sensitive, director Peter Farrelly skillfully circumvents the brute confrontation as it transports our attention deep down into a terrain of feel-good introspection. Based on real life, the film ventures largely to anticipate the expected— and the unexpected offshoot therein. Thanks to the remarkable Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali, both in their A-games, who convincingly imparted a palpable juxtaposition of sharp contrasts. Tony Vallelonga (Mortensen), aka Tony Lip within his circle, is a semi-illiterate, garrulous, straight-talking, hard-hitting New York nightclub bouncer. For an Italian-American whose work ethics simply means doing his job up to the last jab, a one-hit punch to avert trouble seems like an easy routine. During his hiatus from the club, he was bound to find a job to make ends meet for his wife and kids in a tightly-knit working class Bronx neighborhood. Dr. Don Shirley (Ali), wealthily residing above the famous Carnegie Hall is a hands-down music virtuoso who could dexterously play out sentiments through his keyboards. A double doctorate in his expertise, he possesses an elegant demeanor, and the kind of finesse required of his reputation as a renowned musical genius. A New York native of Jamaican descent, Dr. Don occupies the upper strata of society, a rarity for such a colored man of his time. Nonetheless, listening to a long list of credits would convey a realization that giftedness much like skin tone is indeed inborn. Heeding the racial dangers that lie ahead as his trio heads toward the Deep South for a concert tour in 1962, Dr. Don calculatingly hires Tony to be his chauffeur (and eventual protector), as there’s no other man who can truly deliver. After dispute and reluctance, Tony— whose previous motorist experience was limited to driving a garbage truck—-accepts the package priced more than enough to change a man’s heart. Traveling under one roof within each other’s distance, Tony and Don’s exchanges reveal a wide chasm deeply rooted on how things are or should be—- depending on who’s talking. The salient disparity between the driver’s and passenger’s minds or manners are mutually educative. As the trip digs southern on multi-state accommodations and appearances, so does the observance of racism dig deeper. Testing their resilience, events can turn differences into commonality, disagreements into friendship as both navigate the challenging Jim Crow era of the South. Mortensen, sporting a conspicuous beer belly from presumably gobbling up a truckload of pepperonis prior to portraying the part, delivered for the most laughs. His limited vocabulary automatically twitching his tongue to a crisp usage of “sh*t” with gusto can certainly tickle you. Meanwhile, Ali’s imposing screen presence is quite persuasive, his diction inductive. He casts a picture perfect of a black man whose success deserves respect, but not a guarantee to bend social rules. For all its classic one-liners neatly packed in a 130-minute jarring ride, the film demands your full attention. After all, the heart isn’t black or white.
This is how it was in the ‘60’s. Beautifully written and played. Dark but uplifting. Sad and hilarious. See it!
Very enjoyable movie! The leads were very believable. And, it’s a true story!
Well-cast, beautifully shot, and hard-hitting, this true '60s southern tour movie doesn't spell out its characters for us in full clarity, but the humor and direct drama are where it shines.

Green Book takes a potentially bumpy subject matter and delivers a surprisingly entertaining and smooth ride through it, with two perfectly matched leads behind the wheel and in the back seat and an unexpectedly mature effort from director, Peter Farrelly!

I enjoyed this film tremendously. I'm a huge fan of period pieces and particularly films that focus on the interplay of two strong actors. Being a true story of the plight of African Americans dealing with overt racism in the South, this film captures the specific hardship of a genius African American pianist who's oppressed and discriminated against because of his skin color. Acting is top notch and the writing is perfect.

My husband and I went to see Saturday night and the theater was packed.  Intelligent viewers only!  You will laugh and enjoy yourself immensely.  Great acting, great story.  Absolutely beautiful movie.
Not as good as I expected it to be, considering the ratings. But a movie I'd still recommend to to drama fans.  The acting is very good.
Oscar bait done right.

What a perfect film for the holiday season! Peter Farrelly directs a superb film full of hilarious comedic moments, and the most crucial dramatic moments flawlessly blended. This is an important film - based on a true story - about race and acceptance in the 1960s Southern United States. And talk about perfect chemistry! Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali, always stunning, they've done it again in these roles. This is the type of harmony from two actors you don't see very often on-screen, and these two are such a treat in this film. Their character development throughout this journey, both of them, it's amazing to witness. The adversity they both face, the struggles with each other as well as with their own identities, down to the understandings they reach, really makes them stand out as performers.

Honestly, I believe this film has to be a, if not THE frontrunner for best picture, with Mortensen and Ali definitely going head to head, seeing a lot of awards season love. Viggo Mortensen completely transformed in this role, absolutely left me speechless after the fact! And one of the film's final scenes, taking place in a jazz club, it is one of my favorites of the year - such an incredible, feel-good moment. I love this film and I cannot wait to see it again and again! It has shot straight up into my Top 5 of the year no doubt, and I truly hope you can get out and see it as well. This story offers so much, I don't think you'll walk away disappointed.

Brilliant wonderful movie; very well done; the two main actors deserve Oscar consideration. There was a great of fabulous humor and it was a feel good civil rights movie. Very Dow to earth. Best movie that I have seen in last 6 months

I  LOVE TRUE STORYS'

During the 50's and 60's, my family in Colorado often took car trips to visit relatives "down South" -- a dangerous place and a humiliating travel experience for African Americans. I was an adult before I learned my Dad, a WW II veteran, always traveled with his service revolver in the glove box during those trips through the Jim Crow Delta. What a horrible time. This movie did a great job depicting the dangers and the challenges of being black in a nation whose laws and practices said we didn't count. I'll be forever grateful to my late parents for going the extra mile, literally, to keep our family safe and make us feel valued and worthy of dignified treatment. Even when signs said "whites only allowed" my Dad let us know that we mattered, too. With thanks to "Green Book" for sending the same message -- and sharing it in a powerful story about interracial friendship and change. Highly recommended.
this movie was outstanding. The acting ws terrific buy the three stars. The directing was also very well done!!!!!
Definitely seeing this one again - Just incredibly funny.

Incredible. Laughing and tearing up the whole film. One of the best movies I’ve seen all year.
strong performances and a great story
This was an exceptional movie. Entertaining and emotional. Don't miss this one. oh, where did my Viggo Mortensen go! He was delightful!

Green book is a very good movie with a very good lesson about Dr. Don Shirley a Black Musician trying to tour in the south and how the 1960s dealt with racism all while being accompained by Ton Lip a tough Italian guy who bounces at the Copacabana who has a wild personality and some times gets out of hand  . The plot was highly interesting and the way it was filmed was really good aswell and in this day in age with no cgi thats saying alot because this movie had no cgi. I don't think they could have casted a better group of actors to play in this movie  everyone in my opinion worked real hard to make this movie good. the relationship between  Dr. Don Shirley and Tony Lip had everything from laughs,drama and also sadness and pain. Back to the storyline while pretty simple it did indeed get very deep when it came to racism and all the evil it causes and  especially in the south where it did get alot worse but it also showed that in states up in the north while they might as not be as racist as those in the south they were still not totally willing to accept other races fully . Now usually the movies that I like(Marvel for example) never win any type of an award I think this could have a chance to win an oscar. This isn't going to be considered a block buster because it simply won't rake in hundreds of millions of dollars but its still a good movie and worth seeing.

Such a great movie with fantastic actors Viggo Mortensen and Marhershala Ali who brought so much to this true story about two men from totally opposite sides of the cultural spectrum take a two month road trip together to the south where they both were out of their perspective culture zones. Although they didn't "walk in each other's shoes," they walked close enough and through enough for each to change their perspectives of the other and to learn something from one another; ultimately becoming life long friends. The title of this movie comes from a road guide for Blacks to travel during the 1960s. And travel this movie does. Starring Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali, and directed by none other than Peter Farrelly, "Green Book" is a powerful tale about the lessons of manners, and it can effect people of different skin color. While the one of the film can be a little derailing in certain regards, and the movie does play more for fiction than history, the experience is still a good one. "Green Book" is a rather interesting and compelling look at how friendship and manners can come from the most unlikely of places.

The story is set in the year 1962, where Tony Lip (Mortensen) is a regular guy living in The Bronx. One day, Tony gets an offer that feels to crazy to pass up. Tony is given the opportunity to drive Dr. Don Shirley (Ali), a rather popular jazz pianist, on a tour in the deep south of the United States. Where racial tension is at its highest. Now, both Tony and Don must get along with each other, otherwise tensions will rise.

What makes "Green Book" stand out is with the setting and its main leads.

Both Mortensen and Ali have perfect chemistry whenever they are together. Mortensen plays the tough guy from New York, who thinks a loud mouth will solve pretty much everything. Meanwhile, on the other end of the spectrum, Ali plays a seemingly cool and quiet persona, who does have a way with words, in a more sophisticated mannerism. Whenever these two converse and clash with each other, it feels like the audience is truly invested in what is happening on screen, and what sort of outcome will be unveiled.

It also gives the viewer insight into how people are portraying themselves. And, it delves into how manners need to still be adressed.

As for the rest of the cast, while there isn't a lot of attention focused here, they still deliver a good job with what they are given.

The costumes look like something out of the 1960s, and they fit the characters well. In fact, the look of the film itself is quite amazing as it replicates the time period of the decade very well. Especially with the automobiles, which look incredible seeing them run after nearly half a decade on the road.

The pacing of this movie is just perfect. At a little over two hours, the film does take its time introducing the set up, but once it gets going, the audience will have an enjoyable time with these two characters.

The music is also keen on representing the style being played. Plus, with an orchestrated score by Kris Bowers, the movie does have a lively jazz feel its soundtrack.

Now, onto the subject of the film's director: Peter Farrelly. Known for more over the top comedies with his brother, Bobby, and venturing into the more gross out style of humor, this is Peter's first foray into the world of drama. It's a neat little experiment, and Peter tries to blend both the comedy and the drama fine.

This, however, leads into the biggest issue with the film: the tone.

Judging by the promotional material, one would assume that this would be a historical drama. In fact, there is more comedic moments than there are dramatic. If the film had kept a consistent tone, then the movie would have been perfect. Also, because of this, the does tend to stray away from fact, and relate more fiction than anything else.

"Green Book" is just like the travel guide. It is an interesting experience, with a few bumps along the way. But by the end, the viewer will have a good time with themselves.

I was very hesitant about going to see "Green Book" starting with it being directed by Peter Farrelly who was known for such 'low' films as "Dumb and Dumber" and "There's Something About Mary" which dealt with obscene language and scenes though big hits. It also sounded to me like a takeoff of "Driving Miss Daisy" only with a white driver and a black passenger which would probably be 'Hollywoodized" and "the Odd Couple" thrown in as the arc of the movie and it is..

I went only because I am a long time fan of Viggo Mortensen and was impressed with Mahershala Ali in "Moonlight". I expected to see a so-so film with good performances and we certainly saw the latter but it won me over showing the Carnegie Hall apartments, though I never did see one like Ali had. Also the scenes supposedly filmed in the Bronx was not a Bronx I was raised in but all of a sudden I was laughing and then being touched and going through layers of emotions.

Yes Viggo Mortensen as Tony Vallelonga and Mahershala Ali as Dr. Don Shirley are cliches in many scenes but they are both such good actors you believe what they are saying and doing not to forget the touch of family that Linda Cardellini as Tony's wife brings to an Italian Bronx thug who does love his wife and 2 sons, along with other family members.

Based on a true story I must admit I had never heard of Dr. Don Shirley but his story of being a black entertainer who is going to travel through the south in 1962 it is reasonable that he would hire a Tony 'type' to be his chauffer and, in a sense, protector. A lot of cliches are nothing more than stereotypes and much what we see and hear of Shirley and Vallelonga sound and seem familiar which is sad because we aren't surprised.

"Green Book" is being sold as 'a true story of a friendship' and it is just that with many laughs and tears supplied by two brilliant actors who bring more to the script than the script brings to them. There are a couple of scenes that took me by surprise which if talked about would mean spoilers and should be discovered on their own but one question I would love if anyone knows if  Mahershala does his own piano playing or is it Hollywood magic?

Both "Green Book" and "The Hate U Give" are two of the best films I have seen this autumn and though both deal with race they are completely different and also have leading performances that should get nominations , if not actual wins, for their performances.

Who would've thought that Peter Farrelly, director of such slapstick hits as 'Dumb and Dumber' and 'There's Something About Mary,' could make a smart, insightful, movie exploring race dynamics and tensions that easily qualifies as one of the best movies of the year? 
Farrelly perfectly mixes wholesome, breezy fun with intelligent themes regarding race and identity while Viggo Mortensen and Ali Mahershala dig into their characters with resounding success. Shirley's struggle to overcome his prescribed black identity and the prejudiced qualities associated with it resonated deeply with me, though the conflict isn't resolved quite as well as it could be given how uncomfortably antagonistic Shirley's viewpoints against his own people can get. Similarly, Mortensen's Tony Lip, while incredibly acted, is limited in his overall development as he grows past the time period's rampant racism pretty quickly and without enough fanfare. The third act of the film suffers from some repetitive pacing as a result, never quite knowing when to cut a scene or just skip to the end.
Still, these complaints are minor in the overall context of the great film, and will likely pass undetected by most viewers given how enjoyable 'Green Book' is.

TheReelness.com: The Negro Motorist Green Book” was an annual travel guide for black Americans from the 1930s through the mid 1960s, informing them of establishments where they were welcomed in the segregationist Deep South. When world class pianist Dr. Don Shirley (Mahershala Ali) decides to tour the region in 1962, he hires a street smart, working class Italian-American from the Bronx (Viggo Mortensen) to serve as his driver and bodyguard. Director Peter Farrelly, half of the brother duo behind gross-out comedies Dumb and Dumber and Something About Mary, deftly ticks all of the emotional boxes in this more grown up, feel good, buddy flick based on a true story - a Driving Miss Daisy/Thelma and Louise mashup with switched up races and genders. And it works, thanks to cute, crowd pleasing humor, impeccable art direction that transports moviegoers back in time, and charismatic, nuanced performances from Ali (Moonlight) and Mortensen, capturing the unexpected friendship that evolved between the two men during one of the nation’s more shameful eras. A-

The actors also performed brilliantly and they truly deserve to get nominated. Highly recommend!

Peter Farrelly's uncharacteristic biopic Green Book centers itself on Italian-American bouncer Tony "Lip" Vallelonga's agreement to be both driver and security for African-American classical pianist Don Shirley as they embark on a tour of the American South in 1962 during what would become the final years of Jim Crow segregation. Building itself on a mix of light comedy and strong drama with a conciliatory tone, the film lacks much of the divisive polemics of recent Hollywood films on race relations, all without pulling any punches its display of white Southern racism.

In a similar manner as 2016's Moonlight, it also places much emotional weight on the "black outsider" whose cultural interests, sexual identity and outlook are at odds with both the commonplace white and black expectations of the conception of African-American cultural identity. In doing so, the film poses hard questions on all sides, helping it to eschew the more simplistic "oppressor vs. oppressed" narratives on race provided by the likes of Spike Lee, Ava DuVernay or Boots Riley.

Despite this nicer way of exploring a contentious issue, Green Book's bright-eyed sentiment feel somewhat out of step with modern sensibilities in regard to social change. Coming off as being in between Driving Miss Daisy and The Help, Green Book services a desire to get past a certain nationality animosity (reflected in its widespread popularity among audiences) but appears more suited for an era where reason and decency are of a higher value than passion and rage. If you can, enjoy the conceptional conclusions of the film. If not, Blackkklansman is probably more to your liking. However, I prefer the former.

Green Book is a nice and enjoyable film. The two leads are easily the best parts of the film. Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali were excellent in the film. They have great chemistry together. I wouldn’t be shocked to hear either of their names come Oscar nomination time. Unfortunately, the rest of the film isn’t as good as the performances. The script is very shallow. It doesn’t delve enough into its themes. Some of the dialogue isn’t great as well. The story is nice but the film isn’t perfect. Overall, I don’t understand all the Oscar buzz for the film. It makes sense for the performances, but the film is a basic and cliched comedy/drama. It’s a fine watch, but it doesn’t really stick with you.

Superb acting, but superbly predictable. I knew going in that Mr. Mortensen and Mr. Ali would do great. I was pleasantly rewarded not only by their acting, which was great as expected, but by the fun and emotional interactions between the characters. I had huge smiles on my face with some of their interactions, and a deep feeling of sadness during others. Again, they were great and were the main reason I give this movie a 7.25/10. My problems arise with the script. I just don’t think the racism aspect was handled as well as it could have been outside the relationship of the two. All of the encounters with racist men and women felt a bit dumbed down and not as destructive as they should have been. Racism is a brutal subject, and I think it deserved to be shown that way and handled in a stronger way. While I understand this movie wanted to help the audience feel good and show that people can bond together, I definitely thought it could still do that while increasing the realistic aspect of the racism these people would have experienced, and therefore giving more respect to the two main characters for overcoming so much more than was shown. And the ending especially just kinda felt like a cop-out. Tony tells someone to be quiet about racism one time at the table and the whole family opens Mr. Shirley with open arms? Even if that’s how it went down, that they all ate Xmas dinner together, I don’t think the opinion of Mr. Shirley with some members of Tony’s family shifted that quick. You knew what was going to happen because of what kind of movie it established itself as. I appreciate what the director and writers were going after and in no way do I see their portrayal of this story as racist, I just think it could have been a little more realistic and that would have made the film’s impact even greater. +acting -script choices

It now seems a given every year that it is not an Oscar race unless we have a film like The Help or Hidden Figures, and so the LFF Surprise Film brings us this year's ain't-we-racist-back-then worthy Oscar contender in Peter Farrelly's film based on the real life friendship between Don Shirley, a preen and pristine black pianist who decides to go on tour in a segregated American South in 1962 and his driver/bodyguard, a rough and ready Italian-American family man by the name of Tony Lip. Whilst it might be easy to dismiss this as an inverted Driving Miss Daisy (with bits of My Fair Lady and Cyrano de Bergerac thrown in for good measure) this has a more politically aware and acceptable racial role reversal going for it. Through the eyes of Tony, we encounter a gradually escalating set of injustices and prejudices Shirley had to endure because of his skin colour as they head deeper south and via this enlightening experience, Tony goes through a redemptive arc that begins with him having similar prejudices due to his ignorance and finishes with him rejecting and turning around his erroneous ways just in time for Christmas. Pegged as a mainstream feel-good film, Farrelly, known previously for very different films when he was directing with his brother Bobby, brings a light touch to the subversive drama (another influence here I reckon is In the Heat of the Night) but equally surprising and astonishing are the transformative central performances by Mahershala Ali and Viggo Mortensen, in which, shedding previous roles they are known for to inhibit almost polar opposite ones here, both actors show range unseen before in an impressive pair of portrayals that are believable, heart-warming and simply inspirational.

"Green Book" explores a subject that has been countless times in cinema before, but manages to stay unique due to the stellar performances from both Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali. The exchanges of dialogue between these two very different, both flawed, yet ultimately likable characters are the best parts of this film. I can definitely foresee this movie picking up a few nominations come awards season. I thought the story kept my interest and the movie balanced dramatic and humorous moments well. However, the movie feels like a series of similar events happening over and over again, so sometimes the experience becomes a bit repetitive. Overall, the film explores themes that have been done before but is worth checking out due to the two outstanding lead performances.

What easily could have been a stereotypical or cliche road trip movie involving opposing leads turns out to be a nuanced, funny, and touching portrayal of the complexities individuals lives were in the early 1960s not only in the Deep South but in northern states as well. Thanks in no small part to a witty script, deft directing, and fantastic chemistry between Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali, Green Book proves to be a film of coming together that is desperately needed nowadays.
